Also refers to flat surfaces extending behind '''splitters''' in sedan and GT based racing cars. ==V== ;Victory lane: Also 'Winner's Circle,' because of early motorsport's roots at horse racing tracks, the American term for the place where the winner of a race goes to celebrate victory after winning an event.{{cite web|url=http://www.nascar.com/kyn/101/glossary/index_T_Z.html|title=NASCAR Glossary T-Z|publisher=NASCAR|accessdate=6 December 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100218001847/http://www.nascar.com/kyn/101/glossary/index_T_Z.html|archivedate=18 February 2010}} ;[[Victory lap]]: A lap, after the conclusion of the race, where the winning racer drives at reduced speed to celebrate his or her victory. ==W== ;The Wally: In the NHRA, The Wally is the nickname of the trophy that is earned by the winner of an event, the nickname refers to the founder of the NHRA, [[Wally Parks]]. ;Wallies: A slower car, usually found at the rear of the grid. It is sometimes a derogatory term. ;Wastegate: Device attached to [[turbocharger]]s used to limit the additional horsepower they produce. Usually a mechanical device, activated when the pressure within the turbocharger reaches a certain point, opening a valve, thus reducing boost pressure. Used primarily for safety (speed reduction of the racing cars) or cost (reducing stress on both turbo and engine, lengthening the life of the parts prior to failure or rebuild). Not to be confused with a Blow-Off Valve. ;Wear the shiny off: A term used, mostly within drag racing, when a brand new car either hits the wall, or, in the Pro Stock class, when a new car flips over into its top and continues down the track for a considerable length, peeling the paint, or more common in recent years, [[wrap advertising|vinyl wrap]], off. ;Weight shifting: A technique used to reduce understeer. This involves the driver decelerating through a corner to shift the weight of the car from the back to the front, increasing grip of the front tyres and decreasing understeer. ;Wet (or wet-weather) tyre: A racing tyre with deep grooves designed to displace standing water, allowing the tyre to obtain grip in conditions where dry weather tyres ('''slicks''') would '''aquaplane'''. '''Monsoon wet''' has become a term used for extremely wet conditions. ;Wheel banging: When the wheels of two different race cars slightly collide during an overtaking manoeuvre.{{cite news|url=http://www.f1technical.net/glossary/w|title=F1 technical glossary |publisher=[[F1technical]]|accessdate=22 January 2009}} ;Wheel hop: (drag racing) violent shaking of the car as the tires lose and regain traction in quick succession. [[File:MaynardYingst SprintCar.jpg|thumb|right|[[Maynard Yingst]] performing a wheelie in his [[sprint car racing|sprint car]]]] ;[[Hubcap#Motorsport use|Wheel shroud]]: also known as aero cover or rim blanking. A wheel cover designed to distribute airflow to the brakes, thereby generate downforce. Saw common use in the [[Group C]] era, Indycar up to 1993 when banned and in F1 between 2006 and 2009.{{Cite web|url=http://www.motorsportads.com/race-engine-technology/ret-formula-one-technology.htm#wheelshrouds|title=Race Engine Technology : Formula One Technology|website=www.motorsportads.com|access-date=2016-06-12}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.racecar-engineering.com/articles/f1/wind-cheaters-10-ways-f1-teams-increase-top-speed/|title=Wind Cheaters - 11 ways F1 teams increase top speed (UPDATED)|last=Collins|first=Sam|date=2013-09-06|website=[[Racecar Engineering]]|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-12}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.formula1-dictionary.net/wheel_shrouds.html|title=Wheel Shrouds|last=SEAS|website=www.formula1-dictionary.net|access-date=2016-06-12}} ;[[Wheelie]]: In a rear wheel drive vehicle, when the front wheel(s) rise up in the air under acceleration. ;Wheelie bars: (drag racing) rear struts fixed to rear axle, which protrude out to the rear of the car to help prevent a car's front from raising too high or flipping over on launch. [[File:WheelieBarKennyBernstein.jpg|thumb|right|The wheelie bar (foreground) and parachute (gray) on [[Kenny Bernstein]]'s [[Top Fuel]] dragster.]] ;Wheelspin: When the rear tyres (or front tyres in the case of a front wheel drive vehicle) break traction with the racing surface under acceleration, spinning the wheels faster than they move across the surface. On higher traction surfaces like bitumen the tyre will begin to shred and melt from the friction, producing white smoke. ;Wheelstand: wheelie. In drag racing, an extreme case, with front wheels very near vertical. ;Wheelstander: In drag racing, an exhibition car designed to complete a pass in a wheelstand (wheels near vertical) ;Whip: A [[motocross]] technique in which the rider pitch their bike sideways and reposition themselves for the landing whilst airborne.{{cite web|url=http://motomagazine.co.uk/motocross-tips/mx-skills-how-to-whip-a-motocross-bike.html#PIRkXT2b7Oa3Jdvy.97|title=Motocross Skills: How to Whip a motocross bike - Moto Magazine|publisher=motomagazine.co.uk|accessdate=10 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://motocross.transworld.net/features/tuesday-tip-whip-101/#ZHMBHBUSqJ5dfBzx.97|title=Whip 101 | Transworld Motocross|publisher=motocross.transworld.net|accessdate=10 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dirtrider.com/features/protips/141_1102_how_to_whip_it_with_kris_keefer/|title=How To Whip It with Kris Keefer - Pro Riding Secret - Dirt Rider Magazine|publisher=dirtrider.com|accessdate=10 September 2015}} ;Wickerbill: See '''Gurney flap'''. ;Wing: Aerodynamic device on many racing cars. The principle is the same as an aircraft wing except in motor racing applications the wing is inverted to create '''downforce''' instead of lift, pressing the car onto the road surface to increase [[Traction (engineering)|traction]]. ;Wired to the tree: A drag racing term for a racer that consistently beats his opponent off the starting line. Also called ''Chopping down the Christmas Tree''. ;Wishbone: Suspension control arm with three points, shaped roughly like a chicken wishbone. ;Works team: A motor racing team supported by a vehicle manufacturer, usually run in-house at the manufacturer's premises. A '''works driver''' is a driver who drives for the works team. ==Y== ;Yellow chequer: A term derived when the final lap(s) in a race is completed during a '''full course yellow''' while the field is under the control of the ''Safety Car''. In this instance the yellow and chequered flags are waved together and the race is declared finished with the order the same as when the '''full course yellow''' began. Unpopular with spectators because of the anti-climactic nature of the finish, the possibility does make some senior race officials hesitate to use it late in the race, call a red flag to allow for further cleanup of the circuit to ensure a final restart (which is often used anyway for severe debris incidents, especially with carbon fibre), or direct to slow the safety car in order that the hazard may be cleared in time for a competitive race finish. INDYCAR has a Yellow chequer rule, and NASCAR allows it (1) if a race is shortened because of curfew or darkness, (2) if the race is already on its final lap when the yellow must be waved, or (3) if there is a yellow implemented after the leader crosses the "overtime line" (usually located on the backstretch) during a valid [[green-white-checkered]] finish once the race has restarted. In Formula One, when there is a yellow chequer, the safety car will not lead the leader to the finish line, unlike INDYCAR and NASCAR. ==Z== ;Zero car: Used in rallying. Prior to the rally cars running over a ''special stage'' several official vehicles run through the course to check for safety, conditions of the road, to see if spectators or animals may be a hazard or for obstructions. Sometimes there are a triple zero (000) and double zero (00) as well as the zero. Zero cars travel the course immediately ahead of the competitors and are usually rally cars themselves. ;Zero Light: Also known as "'''cutting a zero'''," and a "'''zero R.T'''." Used in drag racing when someone leaves the starting line at the exact moment when the light turns green (.000). Very difficult to achieve, due to the quick flashing of the lights on a Pro tree. ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == *[https://www.webcitation.org/5ixJ6NR2E?url=http://www.formula1.com/inside_f1/glossary.html Formula One glossary] *[http://www.wrc.com/about-wrc/glossary/ World Rally Championship glossary] *[http://www.motogp.com/en/features/Glossary Moto GP glossary] {{Glossaries of sports}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Glossary Of Motorsport Terms}} [[Category:Motorsport terminology| ]] [[Category:Glossaries of sports|Motorsport]]

revision.comment: /* N */ Added definition of "nothing card"
revision.text:
<!-- This is a list of poker terms in common usage in the Wikipedia. Do not add terms used in your home game or that you personally think are clever. If you add a term, please note a reference supporting its inclusion here in the edit summary or this article's discussion page. ADDITIONS THAT ARE JUST SLANG FOR A MORE COMMON TERM USED IN ARTICLES WILL BE REMOVED. --> {{wiktionarycat|type=Poker|category=Poker}}
The following is a '''glossary of poker terms''' used in the card game of [[poker]]. It supplements the [[glossary of card game terms]]. Besides the terms listed here, there are thousands of common and uncommon poker slang terms. This is not intended to be a formal dictionary; precise usage details and multiple closely related senses are omitted here in favor of concise treatment of the basics.
{{Compact ToC|side=yes|x=X|y=Y|z=Z}}
== A == ; {{Anchor|Ace}}ace in the hole : One of the [[#hole|hole cards]] is an ace<ref name="PokerVIP">{{Cite web|url = https://www.pokervip.com/en/poker-terms/|title = Poker Terms|date = |accessdate = |website = PokerVIP|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> ; {{anchor|ace-to-X}} ace-to-five, ace-to-six : Methods of evaluating low hands. See [[Lowball (poker)|lowball]]. ; {{anchor|act}} act : To make a play (check, bet, call, raise, or fold) at the required time, compare to ''[[#in turn|in turn]]''. ; {{Anchor|Acting}}acting out of turn : A player in poker that either announces their actions or physically plays before their turn ( checks, folds etc ). Sometimes players act out of turn intentionally to get a read out of other players. When done intentionally, this is often referred to as "angle shooting." See [[Glossary of poker terms#AngleShooting|angle shooting]].<ref name="PokerVIP"/> ; {{anchor|action}} action : A player's turn to act : A willingness to gamble : A bet, along with all the calls of that bet ; {{anchor|action button}} action button : A marker similar to a [[#kill button|kill button]], on which a player places an extra forced bet. In a [[seven-card stud]] high-low game, the action button is awarded to the winner of a [[#scoop|scoop]] pot above a certain size, signifying that in the next pot, that player will be required to post an amount representing a completion of the [[Betting (poker)#Open|bring-in]] to a full bet. ; {{anchor|action card}} action card : In [[Texas hold 'em]], and other community card poker games, a card appearing on the board that causes significant betting action because it helps two or more players. ; {{anchor|action only}} action only : In many cardrooms, with respect to an all-in bet, only a full (or half) bet can be reraised. Anything less than a full (or half) bet is considered to be ''action only'', that is, other players can call the bet but not raise it. Compare with ''[[#full bet rule|full bet rule]]'' and ''[[#half bet rule|half bet rule]]''. ; {{anchor|active player}} active player : A player still involved in the pot. If there are [[#side pot|side pot]]s, an [[#all in|all-in]] player may be active in some pots, but not in others. ; {{anchor|add-on}} add-on : In a live game, to buy more chips before busting. In [[Poker tournament|tournament]] play, a single rebuy for which all players are eligible regardless of their stack size. This is usually allowed only once, at the end of the rebuy period. The add-on often offers more chips per dollar invested than the buyin and rebuys. Compare with ''[[#rebuy|rebuy]]''. ; {{anchor|advertising}} advertising : To make an obvious play or expose cards in such a way as to deliberately convey an impression to opponents about the advertising player's style of play. ; {{anchor|aggressive}} aggressive, aggression : The tendency for a player to open betting or raise rather than call or check. See main article: [[aggression (poker)|aggression]]. Compare with ''[[#loose|loose]]'', ''[[#tight|tight]]'', ''[[#passive|passive]]''. ; {{anchor|aggression factor (AF)}} aggression factor (AF) : A measure of a player's aggression, either in a particular betting round or over all betting rounds ; {{anchor|air}} air : In [[Lowball (poker)|lowball]], ''giving air'' is when a player lets an opponent who might otherwise fold know that they intend to draw one or more cards, to induce them to call. : A dead hand ; {{anchor|all in}} all in : When a player bets all of their chips in the current hand. See main article: [[Betting (poker)#"All in"|all in]]. ; {{anchor|angle}} angle : A permitted, but borderline unethical, play ; {{Anchor|AngleShooting}}angle shooting : A player acting out of turn to get a read on their opponents. See [[Glossary of poker terms#acting|acting out of turn]]. ; {{anchor|ante}} ante : A forced bet required, in some types of poker, of all players before the hand begins. See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Ante|ante]]. ; {{anchor|ante off}} ante off : In [[Poker tournament|tournament]] play, to force an absent player to continue paying antes, blinds, bring-ins, and other forced bets so that the contest remains fair to the other players. Also ''[[#blind off|blind off]]''. ; {{anchor|any two}} any two cards : An expression used in [[Texas hold 'em]] to say that a player's cards do not matter in a decision
== B == ; {{anchor|backdoor}} backdoor : A draw requiring two or more rounds to fill : A hand made other than the hand the player intended to make ; {{anchor|back in}} back in : To enter a pot by checking and then calling someone else's [[Betting (poker)#Open|open]] on the first betting round. Usually used in games like [[Five-card draw|jackpots]], meaning to enter without openers. ; {{anchor|back into}} back into : To win a pot with a hand that would have folded to any bet ; {{anchor|backraise}} backraise : A [[#reraise|reraise]] from a player who previously [[#call|called]] in the same betting round ; {{anchor|bad beat}} bad beat : To lose a hand where one hand is considerably ahead of the eventual winning hand. See main article: [[bad beat]]. ; {{anchor|balance}} balance : Playing very different hands in the same way, with the aim of making it more difficult for an opponent to gain useful information about the cards a player has. ; {{anchor|bank}} bank : Also called the ''house'', the person responsible for distributing chips, keeping track of the buy-ins, and paying winners at the end of the game. ; {{anchor|bankroll}} bankroll : The amount of money that a player has to wager for the duration of his or her poker career : To fund someone's participation in a game. Compare with ''staking''. ; {{anchor|bankroll management}} bankroll management : Choosing the correct stakes and game type to avoid exhausting a bankroll during downswings ; {{anchor|behind}} behind : Not (currently) having the best hand : Money on the table but not currently in the pot, which can be bet later in the hand : Money in play but not visible as chips in front of a player ; {{anchor|bet}} bet : Any money wagered during the play of a hand : The [[Betting (poker)#Open|opening]] bet of a betting round : In a [[Betting (poker)#Fixed limit|fixed limit]] game, the standard betting amount ; {{anchor|betting structure}} betting structure : The complete set of rules regarding forced bets, limits, raise caps, and such for a particular game. See main article: [[betting (poker)|betting]]. ; {{anchor|big bet}} big bet : The larger of two bet amounts in a fixed limit game. See main article: [[big bet]]. ; {{anchor|big bet game}} big bet game : A game played with [[Betting (poker)#No limit|no limit]] or a [[Betting (poker)#Pot limit|pot limit]] betting structure ; {{anchor|big blind}} big blind : The larger of two forced bets in certain types of poker. See main article: [[blind (poker)|blind]]. ; {{anchor|big blind special}} big blind special : A hand won by the big blind playing very weak pocket cards because there was no raise pre-flop ; {{anchor|big full}} big full : The best possible full house in community card games. A stronger hand than the ''[[#underfull|underfull]]''. ; {{anchor|big stack}} big stack : A stack of chips that is relatively large for the stakes being played. Also called ''[[#deep stack|deep stack]]''. Also the biggest stack at the table. Compare with ''[[#short stack|short stack]]''. ; {{anchor|blank}} blank : A card, frequently a [[community card]], of no apparent value. Compare with ''[[#rag|rag]]'', ''[[#brick|brick]]'', ''bomb''. ; {{anchor|blaze}} blaze :A [[non-standard poker hand]] of five [[face card]]s that outranks a [[Flush (poker)|flush]] ; {{anchor|bleed}} bleed :To consistently lose chips through bad play, possibly resulting from [[#tilt|tilt]]ing ; {{anchor|blind}} blind : A type of forced bet. See main article: [[blind (poker)|blind]]. : In the [[#dark|dark]] ; {{anchor|blind defense}} blind defense : To [[#Betting in poker|call or raise]] an opponent's raise when in the [[#big blind|big blind]], rather than folding an otherwise weak hand, in order to exploit overly [[Aggression (poker)|aggressive]] players.<ref name="ps glossary">[http://www.pokerstrategy.com/glossary/ PokerStrategy Glossary]</ref> ; {{anchor|blind steal}} blind steal : A [[Betting in poker|raise]] from a late position with a weak hand when all other players have folded, with the intention of winning the [[Blind (poker)|blinds]] and [[#ante|antes]].<ref name="ps glossary" /> ; {{anchor|blind stud}} blind stud :A [[stud poker]] game in which all cards are dealt face down. Was popular in California before legal rulings made traditional stud legal there. ; {{anchor|blind off}} blind off, blinded : To [[#ante off|ante off]] : When a player's stack is reduced by paying ever increasing blinds in tournaments ; {{anchor|blocker}} blocker : In [[community card poker]], holding one of the opponent's [[Out (poker)|outs]], typically when the board threatens a straight or straight draw. A ''blocker'' is also having a combination of cards that turn your opponent's outs into your own. Compare with ''[[#dry ace|dry ace]]''. ; {{anchor|blocking bet}} blocking bet : An abnormally small bet made by a player out of position intended to discourage a larger bet by an opponent ; {{anchor|bluff}} bluff : A bet made with a hand that is mathematically unlikely to be the best hand, either to make money or to disguise play patterns. See main article: [[bluff (poker)|bluff]]. ; {{anchor|bluff catching range}} bluff catching range : The number of hands that do not have any real value left on the [[#river|river]], but might still be good enough to catch the [[#bluff|bluff]] of an opponent<ref name="ps glossary" /> ; {{anchor|bluff induce}} bluff induce : To make an [[#aggression|aggressive]] move with a strong hand to give the impression it is a [[#bluff|bluff]], in order to draw a bluff from an opponent ; {{anchor|board}} board : The set of [[community card]]s in a [[Community card poker|community card game]] : The set of face-up cards of a particular player in a [[Stud poker|stud]] game : The set of all face-up cards in a stud game ; {{anchor|boat}} boat : Another name for a [[Full house (poker)|full house]] ; {{anchor|both ways}} both ways : Both halves of a [[High-low split|split pot]], often declared by a player who thinks he or she will win both low and high ; {{anchor|bottom dealing}} bottom dealing : Trick or cheating deal where a card or cards are dealt from the bottom of the deck rather than the top. See main article: [[bottom dealing]]. ; {{anchor|bottom end}} bottom end : The lowest of several possible [[Straight (poker)|straights]], especially in a [[Community card poker|community card game]]. Also ''[[#idiot end|idiot end]]''. ; {{anchor|bottom X}}{{anchor|bottom pair}}{{anchor|bottom set}} bottom pair, bottom set : In a [[Community card poker|community card game]], a pair (or set) made by matching the lowest-ranking board card with one (or two) in one's private hand. Compare [[#second pair|second pair]], [[#top pair|top pair]]. ; {{anchor|bounty}} bounty : An aspect of some poker tournaments that rewards players for eliminating other players with a cash prize for each player they eliminate, separate from the tournament payout structure. See main article: [[Bounty (poker)|bounty]]. ; {{anchor|box}} box : The chip tray in front of a house dealer, and by extension, the house dealer's position at the table ; {{anchor|boxed card}} boxed card : A card encountered face-up in the assembled deck during the deal, as opposed to one overturned in the act of dealing. Most house rules treat a boxed card as if it does not exist; that is, it is placed aside and not used. Different rules cover cards exposed during the deal. ; {{anchor|break}} break : In a [[draw poker]] game, to discard cards that make a [[made hand]] in the hope of making a better one. In a jacks-or-better draw game, a player breaking a high pair must keep the discarded card aside, to prove they had openers. : To end a session of play : During a tournament, an intermission ; {{anchor|brick}} brick : A [[#blank|blank]], though more often used in the derogatory sense of a card that is undesirable rather than merely inconsequential,. Also known as a ''bomb''. Compare with [[#rag|rags]]. ; {{anchor|brick & mortar}} brick and mortar : A ''brick and mortar'' casino is a real [[casino]] based in a building, as opposed to an [[online casino]]. This refers to many real world locations as opposed to their Internet counterparts. ; {{anchor|bridge order}} bridge order : Poker is neutral about suits, but in determining the dealer at the start of a game, or in determining the bringin bettor in a stud game, bridge rank rules are used: spades beat hearts beat diamonds beat clubs. ; {{anchor|bring in}} bring in : To [[Betting (poker)#Open|open]] a betting round : A forced bet in stud games. In the first betting round, the holder of the worst (lowest or highest, depending) upcard must post a bring-in bet. The bring-in bet is typically a quarter to a third of a small bet. The bring-in bettor may look at their cards, and place a full bet if they choose. ; {{anchor|broadway}} broadway : A 10 through ace straight. Can also include any group of cards from 10 to ace. ; {{anchor|brush}} brush : A casino employee whose job it is to greet players entering the poker room, maintain the list of persons waiting to play, announce open seats, and various other duties (including brushing off tables to prepare them for new games, hence the name). : To recruit players into a game ; {{anchor|bubble}} bubble : The last finishing position in a [[poker tournament]] before entering the payout structure ; {{anchor|bubble factor}} bubble factor : The factor by which the [[Pot odds|odds]] in chips differ from the odds in dollars.<ref name="ps glossary" /> See also main article: [[expected value]]. ; {{anchor|buck}} buck : Marker to indicate which player is dealer (or last to act). See [[button (poker)|button]]. ; {{anchor|bug}} bug : A limited wild card. See main article: [[bug (poker)|bug]]. Compare with [[wild card (poker)|wild card]]. ; {{anchor|bully}} bully : A player who raises frequently to force out more cautious players, especially one with a large stack for the size of the game<ref>[http://www.pokerlistings.com/blog/pro-tips/being-a-bully Gus Hansen]</ref> ; {{anchor|burn card}} burn card, burn : A card that is removed from the deal to prevent cheating. See main article: [[burn card]]. ; {{anchor|busted}} busted : An uncompleted hand : To lose all of one's chips ; {{anchor|button}} button : Most commonly a marker that indicates the dealer position at the table, but other specialized buttons exist. See main article: [[button (poker)|button]]. Also ''buck'' or ''hat''. ; {{anchor|buy-in}} buy-in : The minimum required amount of chips that must be bought to become involved in a game or tournament ; {{anchor|buy short}} buy short : To buy into a game for an amount smaller than the normal buy-in ; {{anchor|buy the button}} buy the button : A rule originating in northern California casinos in games played with [[Blind (poker)|blinds]], in which a new player sitting down with the [[Button (poker)|button]] to their right (who would normally be required to sit out a hand as the button passed, then post to come in) may choose to pay the amount of both blinds for this one hand (the amount of the large blind playing as a [[#live|live blind]], and the amount of the small blind as [[Dead money (poker)|dead money]]), play this hand, and then receive the button on the next hand as if they had been playing all along. See [[public cardroom rules (poker)|public cardroom rules]]. : A tactic most often used by late-position players: a raise to encourage the later and button players to fold, thus giving the raiser last position in subsequent betting rounds ; {{anchor|buy the pot}} buy the pot : Making a bet when no one else is betting so as to force the other players to fold, thus winning the pot uncontested. A specialized version of this is ''buying the blinds'' by making a large raise in the first round forcing all other players out of the hand.
== C == ; {{anchor|call}} call : To match a bet or raise. See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Call|call]]. ; {{anchor|call the clock}} call the clock : A method of discouraging players from taking an excessively long time to act. When someone calls the clock, the player has a set amount of time in which to make up their mind; if they fail to do so, their hand is immediately declared dead. In tournament play, any player can call a clock. ; {{anchor|calling station}} calling station : A player who frequently calls bets, but rarely raises them. A calling station is usually a loose passive player. See main article: [[calling station]]. ; {{anchor|cap}} cap : A limit on the number of [[Betting (poker)#Raise|raises]] allowed in a betting round. Typically three or four (in addition to the [[Open (poker)|opening]] bet). In most casinos, the cap is removed if there are only two players remaining either at the beginning of the betting round, or at the time that what would have otherwise been the last raise is made. : Also, term for the chip, token, or object placed atop one's cards to show continued involvement with a hand ; {{anchor|cap game}} cap game : Similar to ''cap'' above, but refers to a no-limit or pot limit game with a cap on the amount that a player can bet during the course of a hand. Once the cap is reached, all players remaining in the hand are considered all-in. ; {{anchor|cards speak}} cards speak : See main article: [[cards speak (poker)|cards speak]] ; {{anchor|case card}} case card : The last available card of a certain description ; {{anchor|cash game}} cash game : A game where each hand is played for real money as opposed to tournament play. See main article: [[Cash game|ring game]]. ; {{anchor|cash plays}} cash plays : An announcement, usually by a dealer, that a player who has requested to buy chips and can bet the cash they have on the table in lieu of chips until receiving their chips. In many card rooms, it also refers to the policy that $100 bills may remain on the table and are considered to be in play in cash form, rather than converted to chips. ; {{anchor|cashing}} cashing : Winning a share of the prize money in a tournament ; {{anchor|cashing out}} cashing out : Exchanging chips for cash when leaving a game. Removing money from an online poker site. ; {{anchor|catch}} catch : To receive needed cards on a [[Draw (poker)|draw]]. Often used with an adjective to further specify, ''catch perfect'', ''catch inside'', ''catch smooth''. ; {{anchor|catch up}} catch up : To successfully complete a [[Draw (poker)|draw]], thus defeating a player who previously had a better hand ; {{anchor|catch perfect}} catch perfect : To catch the only two possible cards that will complete a hand and win the pot, often those leading to a straight flush. Usually used in [[Texas hold 'em]]. Compare with ''[[#runner-runner|runner-runner]]''. ; {{anchor|center pot}} center pot : The main pot in a [[table stakes]] game where one or more players are all in ; {{anchor|chase}} chase : To call a bet to see the next card when holding a [[Draw (poker)|drawing hand]] when the [[pot odds]] do not merit it : To continue to play a [[Draw (poker)|drawing]] hand over multiple betting rounds, especially one unlikely to succeed : To continue playing with a hand that is not likely the best because one has already invested money in the pot. See [[sunk cost fallacy]]. ; {{anchor|check}} check : To bet nothing. See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Check|check]]. : A casino chip ; {{anchor|check out}} check out : To fold, in turn, even though there is no bet facing the player. In some games this is considered a breach of the rules equivalent to folding out of turn. ; {{anchor|check-raise}} check-raise : Deceptive play whereby a player initially checks with the intention of raising should another player bet. See main article: [[check-raise]]. ; {{anchor|chip}} chip : A small disk or tablet used in place of money. See [[casino token]]. ; {{anchor|chip declare}} chip declare : A method of declaring intent to play high or low in a split-pot game with declaration. See [[Declaration (poker)|declaration]]. ; {{anchor|chip dumping}} chip dumping : A strategy whereby one player deliberately loses chips to another player. Where players have agreed to take such action together, this is a form of [[collusion]]. ; {{anchor|chip leader}} chip leader : The player currently holding the most chips in a tournament (or occasionally a live no limit game) ; {{anchor|chip race}} chip race : An event in tournament poker where chips of a value lower than the minimum required are removed from play. See main article: [[chip race]]. ; {{anchor|chip up}} chip up : To exchange lower-denomination chips for higher-denomination chips. In [[Poker tournament|tournament]] play, the term means to remove all the small chips from play by rounding up any odd small chips to the nearest large denomination, rather than using a chip race. : To steadily accumulate chips in [[Poker tournament|tournament]] play, typically by winning small pots with minimal risk-taking. ; {{anchor|chop}} chop : To split a pot because of a tie, split-pot game, or player agreement : To play a game for a short time and cash out. Also ''hit and run''. : A request made by a player for the dealer to make change : An agreement by all players remaining in a tournament to distribute the remaining money in the prize pool according to an agreed-upon formula instead of playing the tournament to completion. Usually occurs at the final table of a large tournament. ; {{anchor|chopping the blinds}} chopping the blinds : Ending a hand when all players have folded to the blinds with the blinds being returned to those who paid them. See main article: [[chopping the blinds]]. ; {{anchor|click raise}} click raise : Making the minimum raise. Refers to online poker where players click the raise button without specifying the amount of raise. ; {{anchor|closed}} closed : See main article: [[closed (poker)|closed]] ; {{anchor|coffee housing}} coffee housing : Talking in an attempt to mislead other players about the strength of a hand. This is also called ''speech play''. ; {{anchor|coin flip}} coin flip : A situation where two players have invested all their money in the pot and have a roughly even chance of winning. Also ''race''. ; {{anchor|cold call}} cold call : To call an amount that represents a sum of bets or raises by more than one player. Compare with ''[[#flat call|flat call]]'', ''[[#overcall|overcall]]''. ; {{anchor|cold deck}} cold deck : A "stacked" deck (a deck arranged in a preset order, to effect a specific outcome once dealt) which is deceptively switched with the original deck of cards in play, to benefit a player or the dealer. ; {{anchor|collusion}} collusion : A form of cheating involving cooperation among two or more players. See [[cheating in poker]]. ; {{anchor|color change}} color change, color up : To exchange small-denomination chips for larger ones ; {{anchor|combo}} combo, combination game : A casino table at which multiple forms of poker are played in rotation ; {{anchor|come bet}} come bet, on the come : A bet or raise made with a [[Draw (poker)|drawing]] hand, building the pot in anticipation of filling the draw ; {{anchor|community card}} community card : See main article: [[community card poker]] ; {{anchor|complete hand}} complete hand : See [[made hand]] ; {{anchor|completion}} completion : To raise a small bet up to the amount of what would be a normal-sized bet. See [[table stakes]]. ; {{anchor|connectors}} connectors : Two or more cards of consecutive or close to consecutive rank ; {{anchor|continuation bet}} continuation bet : A bet made after the flop by the player who took the lead in betting before the flop ([[Texas hold 'em]] and [[Omaha hold 'em]]). Also called a c-bet. Compare with ''[[#probe bet|probe bet]]''. ; {{anchor|cooler}} cooler : A situation in which a player holds the second best hand, so strong considering the circumstances, that they are apt to lose the maximum with it no matter how they play it ; {{anchor|countdown}} countdown : The act of counting the cards that remain in the stub after all cards have been dealt, done by a dealer to ensure that a complete deck is being used ; {{anchor|counterfeit}} counterfeit : See main article: [[counterfeit (poker)|counterfeit]]. Also ''[[#duplicate|duplicate]]''. ; {{anchor|cow}} cow : A player with whom one is sharing a buy-in, with the intent to split the result after play. To ''go cow'' is to make such an arrangement. ; {{anchor|cripple}} cripple : In some [[community card poker|community card games]], to ''cripple the deck'' means to have a hand that is virtually impossible for anyone else to catch up to. ; {{anchor|crying call}} crying call : Calling when a player thinks they do not have the best hand ; {{anchor|cut}} cut : See main article: [[Cut (cards)|cut]] ; {{anchor|cut card}} cut card : A distinctive card, usually stiff solid-colored plastic, held against the bottom of the deck during the deal to prevent observation of the bottom card ; {{anchor|cutoff}} cutoff : The seat immediately to the right of the dealer button. In home games where the player on the button actually shuffles and deals the cards, the player in the cutoff seat [[Cut (cards)|cuts]] the deck (hence the name).
== D == ; {{anchor|dark}} dark : An action taken before receiving information to which the player would normally be entitled. Compare with ''blind''. ; {{anchor|dead blind}} dead blind : A [[Blind (poker)|blind]] that is not ''live'', in that the player posting it does not have the option to raise if other players just call. Usually involves a small blind posted by a player entering, or returning to, a game (in a position other than the big blind) that is posted in addition to a live blind equal to the big blind. ; {{anchor|dead button}} dead button : See [[Betting (poker)#When a player in the blinds leaves the game|dead button rule]] ; {{anchor|dead hand}} dead hand : A player's hand that is not entitled to participate in the deal for some reason, such as having been fouled by touching another player's cards, being found to contain the wrong number of cards, being dealt to a player who did not make the appropriate forced bets, etc. ; {{anchor|dead man's hand}} dead man's hand : See main article: [[dead man's hand]] ; {{anchor|dead money}} dead money : See main article: [[dead money (poker)|dead money]] ; {{anchor|deal}} deal : To distribute cards to players in accordance with the rules of the game being played : A single instance of a game of poker, begun by shuffling the cards and ending with the award of a pot. Also called a ''hand'' (though both terms are ambiguous). : An agreement to split [[Poker tournament|tournament]] prize money differently from the announced payouts ; {{anchor|deal twice}} deal twice : In a [[#cash game|cash game]], when two players are involved in a large pot and one is all-in, they might agree to deal the remaining cards twice. If one player wins both times they win the whole pot, but if both players win one hand they split the pot. Also, ''play twice'', ''run it twice''. ; {{anchor|dealer}} dealer : The person dealing the cards : The person who assumes that role for the purposes of betting order in a game, even though someone else might be physically dealing. Also ''[[#button|button]]''. Compare with ''[[#buck|buck]]''. ; {{anchor|dealer's choice}} dealer's choice : A version of poker in which the deal passes each game and each dealer can choose, or invent, a new poker game each hand or orbit. See main article: [[dealer's choice]]. ; {{anchor|declare}} declare : To verbally indicate an action or intention. See [[declaration (poker)|declaration]]. ; {{anchor|declare}} deep stack : A stack of chips that is relatively large for the stakes being played. Also called a ''[[#big stack|big stack]]''. Compare with ''[[#short stack|short stack]]''. ; {{anchor|defense}} defense : Making a play that defends the player against a bluff by forcing the suspected bluffer to fold or invest further ; {{anchor|deuce}} deuce : A two-spot card. Also called a ''duck'', ''quack'', or ''swan''. : Any of various related uses of the number two, such as a $2 limit game, a $2 chip, etc. ; {{anchor|deuce-to-seven}} deuce-to-seven : A method of evaluating low hands. See main article: [[deuce-to-seven low]]. ; {{anchor|dirty stack}} dirty stack : A stack of chips apparently of a single denomination, but with one or more chips of another. Usually the result of inattention while stacking a pot, but may also be an intentional deception. ; {{anchor|discard}} discard : To take a previously dealt card out of play. The set of all discards for a deal is called the ''muck'' or the ''deadwood''. ; {{anchor|dominated hand}} dominated hand : A hand that is extremely unlikely to win against another specific hand, even though it may not be a poor hand in its own right. Most commonly used in [[Texas hold 'em]]. See also [[Domination (poker)|domination]]. ; {{anchor|donk bet}} donk bet : A bet made in early position by a player who did not take the initiative in the previous betting round. ; {{anchor|donkey}} donkey : a weak player, also known as ''[[#fish|fish]]'' or ''donk'' ; {{anchor|door card}} door card : In a [[Stud poker|stud]] game, a player's first face-up card : In [[Texas hold 'em]], the door card is the first visible card of the [[#flop|flop]]. : In [[draw poker]], the sometimes visible card at the bottom of a player's hand. Players will sometimes deliberately expose this card. ; {{anchor|double-ace flush}} double-ace flush : Under [[Non-standard poker hand|unconventional rules]], a flush with one or more [[Wild card (poker)|wild cards]] in which they play as aces, even if an ace is already present ; {{anchor|double belly buster straight draw}} double belly buster straight draw : a combination of hole cards and exposed cards in hold 'em or stud games which does not include four connected cards, but where there are two different ranks of card that complete a straight ; {{anchor|double-board}} double-board, double-flop : Any of several [[Community card poker|community card game]] variants (usually [[Texas hold 'em]]) in which two separate boards of community cards are dealt simultaneously, with the pot split between the winning hands using each board. ; {{anchor|double-draw}} double-draw : Any of several [[draw poker]] games in which the draw phase and subsequent betting round are repeated twice ; {{anchor|double raise}} double raise : The minimum raise in a [[Betting (poker)#No limit|no-limit]] or [[Betting (poker)#Pot limit|pot-limit]] game, raising by just the amount of the current bet. ; {{anchor|double suited}} double suited : An [[Omaha hold 'em]] starting hand where two pairs of [[#suited|suited]] cards are held ; {{anchor|double up}} double up, double through : In a big bet game, to bet all of one's chips on one hand against a single opponent (who has an equal or larger stack) and win, thereby doubling the stack ; {{anchor|downbet}} downbet : Betting a smaller amount than the previous round of betting ; {{anchor|downcard}} downcard : A card that is dealt face-down ; {{anchor|downswing}} downswing : A period during which a player loses more than expected. See also: [[#upswing|upswing]]. ; {{anchor|drag light}} drag light : To pull chips away from the pot to indicate that the player does not have enough money to cover a bet. If their hand wins, the amount is ignored. If not, they must cover the amount out of pocket. This is not allowed at any casino. ; {{anchor|draw}} draw, drawing hand, come hand : See main article: [[draw (poker)|draw]] : A ''drawing hand'' is when a player has a chance to improve their hand to something considerably stronger, typically a straight or a flush, through drawing the required cards on the flop, on the turn or on the river.<ref>{{cite web| last = Wellshuffled| title = Definition of a 'drawing hand'| year = 2009| url = http://www.wellshuffled.com/poker-terms/drawing-hand.htm|accessdate= 2009-11-01}}</ref> ; {{anchor|drawing dead}} drawing dead : Playing a [[Draw (poker)|drawing]] hand that will lose even if successful : Playing a hand that can never improve beyond the opponent's hand ; {{anchor|drawing live}} drawing live : Not drawing dead; that is, [[Draw (poker)|drawing]] to a hand that will win if successful ; {{anchor|drawing thin}} drawing thin : Not drawing completely dead, but [[#chase|chasing]] a draw in the face of poor odds ; {{anchor|drop}} drop : To fold : Money charged by the casino for providing its services, often dropped through a slot in the table into a strong box. See [[#rake|rake]]. : To drop one's cards to the felt to indicate that one is in or out of a game ; {{anchor|dry ace}} dry ace : In [[Omaha hold 'em]] or [[Texas hold 'em]], an ace in one's hand without another card of the same suit. Used especially to denote the situation where the [[#board|board]] presents a flush possibility, when the player does not in fact have a flush, but holding the ace presents some [[Bluff (poker)|bluffing]] or [[Bluff (poker)#Semi-bluff|semi-bluffing]] opportunity and a [[#redraw|redraw]] in case the flush [[draw (poker)|draw]] comes on the turn or the river. Compare with ''[[#blocker|blocker]]''. ; {{anchor|dry board}} dry board : A measure of texture of the community cards. A [[#board|board]] is considered dry when the cards on the table mean that is unlikely or impossible that any player has made a strong hand like a straight or flush. Compare with ''[[#wet board|wet board]]''. ; {{anchor|dry pot}} dry pot : A side pot with no money created when a player goes all in and is called by more than one opponent, but not raised. If subsequent betting occurs, the money will go to the dry pot. ; {{anchor|duplicate}} duplicate : To [[Counterfeit (poker)|counterfeit]], especially when the counterfeiting card matches one already present in one's hand
== E == ; {{anchor|early position}} early position : See [[position (poker)|position]]. ; {{anchor|eight or better}} eight or better : A common qualifier in [[high-low split]] games that use ace-5 ranking. Only hands where the highest card is an eight or less can win the low portion of the pot. ; {{anchor|equity}} equity : One's mathematical [[expected value]] from the current deal, calculated by multiplying the amount of money in the pot by one's probability of winning. If a [[Split (poker)|split]] is possible, the equity also includes the probability of winning a split times the size of that split. ; {{anchor|expectation}} expectation, expected value, EV : See main article: [[expected value]]. Used in poker to mean ''profitability in the long run''. ; {{anchor|exposed card}} exposed card : A card whose face has been deliberately or accidentally revealed to players normally not entitled to that information during the play of the game. Various games have different rules about how to handle this irregularity. Compare with ''[[#boxed card|boxed card]]''.
== F == ; {{anchor|family pot}} family pot : A deal in which every (or almost every) seated player calls the first [[Betting (poker)#Open|opening]] bet. ; {{anchor|fast}} fast : [[Aggression (poker)|Aggressive]] play. Compare with ''speeding''. ; {{anchor|favorite}} favorite : A hand which, when matched against another in a showdown, has an advantage odds-wise over the other. A hand can be called a small or a big favorite depending on how much it is dominating the other. Contrast ''[[#underdog|underdog]]'' where the situations are reversed. Favorites are usually used to compare how two hole cards do against two other hole cards pre-flop. ; {{anchor|feeder}} feeder : In a casino setting, a second or third table playing the same game as the main table, and from which players move to the main game as players are eliminated. Also called a ''must-move table''. ; {{anchor|felt}} felt : The cloth covering of a poker table, whatever the actual material. Metonymically, the table itself. : Showing down a hand while all-in (so there is only felt left in front of the player); either betting all-in and getting called or calling all-in. ; {{anchor|field}} field : All players as a collective in a large tournament. ; {{anchor|fifth-street}} fifth street : The last card dealt to the board in community card games. Also see [[#river|river]]. : The fifth card dealt to each player in stud poker. ; {{anchor|fill}} fill, fill up : To successfully draw to a hand that needs one card to complete it, by getting the last card of a [[Straight (poker)|straight]], [[Flush (poker)|flush]], or [[Full house (poker)|full house]]. ; {{anchor|final table}} final table : The last table in a multi-table poker tournament. The final table is set when a sufficient number of people have been eliminated from the tournament leaving an exact number of players to occupy one table (typically no more than ten players). ; {{anchor|first position}} first position : The playing position to the direct left of the blinds in [[Texas hold 'em]] and [[Omaha hold 'em]], also known as ''[[#under the gun|under the gun]]''. The player in first position must act first on the first round of betting. ; {{anchor|fish}} fish : A weak player. See also [[#donkey|donkey]]. : To chase draws holding a weak hand. Especially when facing aggressive play by another player. ; {{anchor|five of a kind}} five of a kind : A hand possible only in games with [[Wild card (poker)|wild cards]], or a game with more than one deck, defeating all other hands, comprising five cards of equal rank. ; {{anchor|fixed limit}} fixed limit, flat limit : See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Fixed limit|fixed limits]]. ; {{anchor|flash}} flash : Any card which becomes briefly exposed by accident to at least one player must be shown to all the players by the dealer during dealing. The card is said to be ''flashed'' to all players before being discarded to the muck pile. See also [[#exposed card|exposed]]. : Unintentionally showing the bottom of the deck if not using a [[#cut card|cut card]]. : To show one or more downcards from one's hand. ; {{anchor|flat call}} flat call : A [[Betting (poker)#Call|call]], in a situation where one might be expected to [[Betting (poker)#Raise|raise]]. Also ''smooth call''. Compare with ''[[#cold call|cold call]]'', ''[[#overcall|overcall]]''. See [[slow play (poker)|slow play]]. ; {{anchor|float}} float : Calling a bet with the intention of bluffing on a later betting round. ; {{anchor|floorman}} floorman, floorperson : A casino employee whose duties include adjudicating player disputes, keeping games filled and balanced, and managing dealers and other personnel. Players may shout "floor" to call for a floorperson to resolve a dispute, to ask for a table or seat change, or to ask for some other casino service. ; {{anchor|flop}} flop : The dealing of the first three face-up cards to the board, refers also to those three cards themselves. Also see [[#turn|turn]] and [[#river|river]]. ; {{anchor|flop game}} flop game : A [[Community card poker|community card game]]. ; {{anchor|flush}} flush : A hand comprising five cards of the same suit. See [[List of poker hands#Flush|List of poker hands]]. ; {{anchor|fold}} fold : To discard one's hand and forfeit interest in the current pot. See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Fold|fold]]. ; {{anchor|fold equity}} fold equity : The portion of the pot one expects to win, on average, by a bet that induces opponents to fold, rather than seeing the showdown. See also [[#equity|equity]]. ; {{anchor|forced bet}} forced bet : See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Forced bets|forced bets]]. ; {{anchor|forced-move}} forced-move : In a casino where more than one table is playing the same game with the same betting structure, one of the tables may be designated the ''main'' table, and will be kept full by requiring a player to move from one of the feeder tables to fill any vacancies. Players will generally be informed that their table is a ''forced-move'' table to be used in this way before they agree to play there. Also ''must-move''. ; {{anchor|forward motion}} forward motion : A house rule of some casinos states that if a player in turn picks up chips from their stack and moves their hand toward the pot (''forward motion with chips in hand''), this constitutes a commitment to bet (or call), and the player may not withdraw their hand to check or fold. Such a player still has the choice of whether to call or raise. Compare with ''[[#string bet|string bet]]''. ; {{anchor|fouled hand}} fouled hand : A hand that is ruled unplayable because of an irregularity, such as being found with too many or too few cards, having been mixed with cards of other players or the muck, having fallen off the table. Compare with ''[[#dead hand|dead hand]]''. ; {{anchor|four-flush}} four-flush : Four cards of the same suit. A [[non-standard poker hand]] in some games, an incomplete [[Draw (poker)|drawing]] hand in most. See main article: [[four flush]]. ; {{anchor|four of a kind}} four of a kind : A hand containing four cards of equal rank. Also ''quads''. See [[List of poker hands#Four of a kind|list of poker hands]]. ; {{anchor|four-straight}} four-straight : Four cards in rank sequence; either an open-ender or one-ender. A [[non-standard poker hand]] in some games, an incomplete drawing hand in most. Sometimes ''four to a straight''. ; {{anchor|fourth street}} fourth street : The fourth card dealt to the board in community card games. Also ''turn''. : The fourth card dealt to each player in stud. ; {{anchor|free card}} free card : A card dealt to one's hand (or to the board of [[community card]]s) after a betting round in which no player [[Betting (poker)#Open|opened]]. One is thereby being given a chance to improve one's hand without having to pay anything. ; {{anchor|freeroll}} freeroll : See main article: [[freeroll (poker)|freeroll]]. ; {{anchor|freezeout}} freezeout : The most common form of [[Poker tournament|tournament]]. There are no [[#rebuy|rebuy]]s and play continues until one player has all the chips. ; {{anchor|full house}} full house, full boat, full hand, full : A hand with three cards of one rank and two of a second rank. Also ''boat'' or ''tight''. See [[List of poker hands#Full house|list of poker hands]]. ; {{anchor|full bet rule}} full bet rule : In some casinos, the rule that a player must wager the full amount required in order for their action to constitute a raise. Compare with ''[[#half bet rule|half bet rule]]''. See [[Public cardroom rules (poker)|public cardroom rules]] and [[Betting (poker)#"All in"|''all in'' betting]]. ; {{anchor|full ring}} full ring : A full ring game is a cash game with more than six players involved, typically nine to eleven. This term is normally used in the context of online poker. Compare with ''[[#shorthanded|shorthanded]]''.
== G == ; {{anchor|gap hand}} gap hand : In [[Texas hold 'em]], a ''gap hand'' is a [[#hole|starting hand]] with at least one rank separating the two cards. Usually referred to in context of ''one-gap'' and ''two-gap'' hands. ; {{anchor|get away}} get away : To fold a strong hand against a supposedly superior hand. Compare with ''[[#laydown|laydown]]''. ; {{anchor|going north}} going north : To sneak additional chips onto the table so as to have effectively bought in above the table limit ; {{anchor|going south}} going south : To sneak a portion of chips from the table while the game is underway. Normally prohibited in public card rooms. Also ''ratholing''. ; {{anchor|grinder}} grinder : A player who earns a living by making small profits over a long period of consistent, conservative play. Compare with ''[[#rock|rock]]''. ; {{anchor|guts}} guts, guts to open : A game with no opening hand requirement : Any of several poker variants where pots accumulate over several hands until a single player wins. ; {{anchor|gut shot}} gut shot, gutshot, gutter : See [[Draw (poker)#Inside straight draw|inside straight draw]] ; {{anchor|gypsy}} gypsy : To enter the pot cheaply by just calling the blind rather than raising. Also ''[[#limp|limp]]''.
== H == <!-- This section is linked from [[Hole]] --> ; {{anchor|half bet rule}} half bet rule : In some casinos, the rule that placing chips equal to or greater than half the normal bet amount beyond the amount required to call constitutes a commitment to [[Raise (poker)|raise]] the normal amount. Compare with ''[[#full bet rule|full bet rule]]''. See [[Betting (poker)#"All in"|"all in" betting]] ; {{anchor|hand}} hand : See main article: [[hand (poker)|hand]] ; {{anchor|hand-for-hand}} hand-for-hand : In [[Poker tournament|tournament]] play, the act of equalizing the number of hands played at two or more tables by waiting for slower tables to finish each hand before beginning the next hand on every table. This is usually done to ensure an accurate finishing order to distribute prize money. ; {{anchor|hand history}} hand history : The textual representation of a hand (or hands) played in an [[Online poker|Internet cardroom]]. See [[poker tools]] ; {{anchor|hanger}} hanger : When the bottom card of the deck sticks out beyond the others, an unwanted tell that the dealer is dealing from the bottom of the deck. ; {{anchor|heads-up}} [[heads up poker]] : Playing against a single opponent ; {{anchor|heater}} heater : See [[#rush|rush]] ; {{anchor|hero call}} hero call : Calling when a player has a relatively weak hand but suspects their opponent may be bluffing ; {{anchor|high hand}} high hand, high : The best hand using traditional [[poker hand]] values, as opposed to [[Lowball (poker)|lowball]]. Used especially in high-low split games. ; {{anchor|high card}} high card : A [[no pair]] hand, ranked according to its highest-ranking cards : To defeat another player by virtue of high-ranking cards, especially [[Kicker (poker)|kickers]] : To randomly select a player for some purpose by having each draw one card, the highest of which is selected (for example, to decide who deals first). ; {{anchor|high-low}} high-low, high-low split : See main article: [[high-low split]] ; {{anchor|hijack}} hijack seat : The seat to the right of the [[#cutoff|cutoff]] seat, or second to the right of the [[Button (poker)|button]]. This is generally considered to be the easiest position to steal the blinds from in tournaments, hence the name. ; {{anchor|hole cards}} {{anchor|hole}} hole cards, hole : Face-down cards. Also ''pocket cards'' : A seat, often preceded by a number relative to the button. ; {{anchor|hole cam}} hole cam : A camera that displays a player's face-down cards (hole cards) to television viewers. Also ''pocket cam'' or ''lipstick cam'' ; {{anchor|home game}} home game : A game played at a private venue (usually the home of one of the players), as opposed to a casino or public cardroom. ; {{anchor|horse}} horse : A player financially backed by someone else. Compare with ''bankroll'' and ''staking'' ; {{anchor|H.O.R.S.E.}} H.O.R.S.E. : See main article: [[H.O.R.S.E.]]
== I == ; {{anchor|ignorant end}}{{anchor|idiot end}} ignorant end, idiot end : In flop games, a player drawing to, or even flopping, a straight with undercards to the flop has the ''idiot end'' of it. A player with 8-9 betting on a flop of A-10-J puts themself at great risk, because many of the cards that complete their straight give credible opponents higher ones. ; {{anchor|implied pot odds}} implied pot odds, implied odds : See main article: [[Pot odds#Implied pot odds|implied pot odds]] ; {{anchor|improve}} improve : To achieve a better hand than one currently holds by adding or exchanging cards as provided in the rules of the game being played. ; {{anchor|inside straight}} inside straight : See [[Draw (poker)#Inside straight draw|inside straight draw]]. Also "belly buster", "gutshot". Compare to [[Draw (poker)#Outside straight draw|outside straight draw]] ; {{anchor|in position}} in position : A player is said to be ''in position'', if the player is last to act on the flop, turn and river betting rounds. Compare with ''out of position'' ; {{anchor|insurance}} insurance : A deal in which players agree to split or reduce a pot (roughly in proportion to the chances of each of them winning) with more cards to come rather than playing out the hand, or a deal where one player makes a side bet against themself with a third party to hedge against a large loss. ; {{anchor|in the middle}} in the middle : In a game with multiple [[Blind (poker)|blinds]], an incoming player may sometimes be allowed to post the blinds ''in the middle'' (that is, out of their normal order) rather than having to wait for them to pass. ; {{anchor|in the money}} in the money : To finish high enough in a [[poker tournament]] to win prize money ; {{anchor|in turn}} in turn : A player is said to be ''in turn'' if that player is expected to act next under the rules. ; {{anchor|irregular declaration}} irregular declaration : An action taken by a player in turn that is not a straightforward declaration of intent, but that is reasonably interpreted as an action by other players, such as pointing a thumb up to signify a raise. [[Public cardroom rules (poker)|House rules]] or dealer discretion may determine when such actions are meaningful and binding. ; {{anchor|irregularity}} irregularity : Any of a number of abnormal conditions in play, such as unexpectedly exposed cards, that may call for corrective action. See [[Public cardroom rules (poker)|public cardroom rules]] ; {{anchor|isolation}} isolation : See main article: [[isolation (poker)|isolation]]
== J == ; {{anchor|jackpot}} jackpot : A game of ''jackpot poker'' or ''jackpots'', which is a variant of [[five-card draw]] with an [[Betting (poker)#Ante|ante]] from each player, no [[Blind (poker)|blinds]], and an [[Open (poker)|opening]] requirement of a pair of jacks or better. : A large pool of money collected by the house and awarded for some rare occurrence, typically a bad beat. ; {{anchor|joker}} joker : A 53rd card used mostly in [[draw poker|draw]] games. The joker may usually be used as an ace, or a card to complete a straight or flush, in high games, and as the lowest card not already present in a hand at low. See [[bug (poker)|bug]] ; {{anchor|juice}} juice : Money collected by the house. Also ''[[#vigorish|vig]]'', ''vigorish''. See [[Rake (poker)|rake]] ; {{anchor|junk}} junk : A hand with little [[expected value]]
== K == ; {{anchor|kicker}} kicker : See main article: [[kicker (poker)|kicker]] ; {{anchor|kill button}} kill button : In a kill game, a button that shows which player has the kill action. See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Kill game|kill game]] ; {{anchor|kill game}} kill game, kill pot : See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Kill game|kill game]] ; {{anchor|kill hand}} kill hand : A hand with different betting rules in a kill game. See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Kill game|kill game]] ; {{anchor|kitty}} kitty : A pool of money built by collecting small amounts from certain pots, often used to buy refreshments, cards, and so on. The home-game equivalent of a rake.
== L == ; {{anchor|lag}} lag : A loose aggressive style of play in which a player plays a lot of starting hands and makes many small raises in hopes of out-playing their opponents ; {{anchor|last to act}} last to act : A player is last to act if all players between the player and the button have folded. ; {{anchor|laydown}} laydown : The choice to fold a strong hand in anticipation of superior opposition ; {{anchor|lead}} lead : The player who makes the last bet or raise in a round of betting is said to have the lead at the start of the next round. Can also be used as a verb meaning ''to bet out into the pot'', ''to lead into the pot''. ; {{anchor|level}} level : Used in tournament play to refer to the size of the blinds that are periodically increased ; {{anchor|leg-up}} leg-up, leg-up button : The button used to signify who has won the previous hand in a kill game ; {{anchor|light}} light : A hand that is not likely to be best. Usually used as an action descriptor; ''call light'', ''three-bet light''. See [[Bluff (poker)#Semi-bluff|semi-bluff]] ; {{anchor|limit}} limit : The minimum or maximum amount of a bet : See [[Betting (poker)#Fixed limit|fixed limit]] ; {{anchor|limp}} limp, limp in : To enter a pot by simply calling a bet instead of raising ; {{anchor|limp-reraise}} limp-reraise : A [[#reraise|reraise]] from a player that previously [[#limp|limped]] in the same betting round. Also ''[[#backraise|backraise]]'' ; {{anchor|live bet}}{{anchor|live}} live bet. : A bet posted by a player under conditions that give them the option to raise even if no other player raises first; typically because it was posted as a [[#blind|blind]] or [[#straddle bet|straddle]]. ; {{anchor|live cards}} live cards : In [[stud poker]] games, cards that will improve a hand that have not been seen among anyone's upcards, and are therefore presumably still available. In games such as [[Texas hold 'em]], a player's hand is said to contain ''live'' cards if matching either of them on the board would give that player the lead over their opponents. Typically refers to a hand that is weak, but not [[#dominated hand|dominated]]. ; {{anchor|live hand}} live hand : A hand still eligible to win the pot; one with the correct number of cards that has not been mucked or otherwise invalidated ; {{anchor|live game}} live game : A game with a lot of [[#action|action]]. See also ''live poker''. ; {{anchor|live poker}} live poker : A retronym for poker played at a table with cards, as opposed to [[video poker]] or [[online poker]] ; {{anchor|lock up}} lock up : To ''lock up'' a seat in a [[#cash game|cash game]] means to place a poker chip, player's card, or other personal effect on the table in front of the seat, to signify that the seat is occupied even though the player may not be present. ; {{anchor|loose}} loose : To play more hands than the average for the game or for the player normally. See [[Poker strategy#Loose/tight play|loose/tight play]]. Compare with ''[[#tight|tight]]'', ''[[#aggressive|aggressive]]'', ''[[#passive|passive]]''. ; {{anchor|low}} low : The lowest card by rank : The low half of the pot in a [[high-low split]]
== M == ; {{anchor|M-ratio}} M-ratio : A measure of the health of a chip stack as a function of the cost to play each round. See main article: [[M-ratio]]. ; {{anchor|made hand}} made hand : A hand that does not need improvement to win. Compare with a ''[[drawing hand]]''. ; {{anchor|maniac}} maniac : A very loose and aggressive player, who bets and raises frequently, and often in situations where it is not good strategy to do so. Opposite of ''[[#rock|rock]]''. ; {{anchor|mark}} mark : A person at a poker table that is the focus of attention, often due to their inexperience ; {{anchor|match the pot}} match the pot : To bet an amount equal to all the chips in the pot ; {{anchor|micro-limit}} micro-limit : Internet poker games with stakes so small that real cardrooms could not profit from them, are said to be at the ''micro-limit'' level. ; {{anchor|middle pair}} middle pair : In a community card game, making a pair with neither the highest nor lowest card of the community cards. See also ''second pair''. ; {{anchor|middle position}} middle position : See [[Position (poker)|position]] ; {{anchor|misdeal}} misdeal : A deal which is ruined for some reason and must be redealt ; {{anchor|missed blind}} missed blind : A required bet that is not posted when it is a player's turn to do so, perhaps occurring when a player absents themself from the table. Various rules require the missed bet to be made up upon the player's return. ; {{anchor|move in}} move in : In a no-limit game, to ''move in'' or to ''go all in'' means to bet one's entire stake on the hand in play. See [[table stakes]]. ; {{anchor|multi-table tournament}} multi-table tournament (MTT) : See [[Poker tournament]] ; {{anchor|muck}} muck : To fold : To discard one's hand without revealing the cards. Often done after winning without a [[Showdown (poker)|showdown]] or at a showdown when a better hand has already been revealed. : The discard pile ; {{anchor|multi-way pot}} multi-way pot : A pot where several players compete for it. Also known as a ''family pot'', although ''family pot'' sometimes means a pot where all players participate.
== N == ; {{anchor|negative freeroll}} negative freeroll : See main article: [[negative freeroll]]. ; {{anchor|nit}} nit : A player who is unwilling to take risks and plays only premium hands in the top range. ; {{anchor|no-limit}} no-limit : Rules designating that players are allowed to wager any or all of their chips in a single bet. See [[Betting (poker)#No limit|no-limit]] ; {{anchor|nosebleed stakes}} nosebleed stakes : also known as '''nosebleed''', is the highest stakes offered in cash game poker, generally where the blinds are at least a minimum of $200/$400<ref name="poke_Nose">{{Cite web| title = Nosebleeds Dictionary Entry| work = Poker-King.com| accessdate = 2017-05-05| url = http://www.poker-king.com/dictionary/nosebleeds/}}</ref><ref name="card_Onli">{{Cite web| title = Online Nosebleed Cash-Game Scene Struggling| author = Pempus, Brian| work = CardPlayer| date = 2011-08-07| accessdate = 2017-05-05| url = http://www.cardplayer.com/poker-news/11810-online-nosebleed-cash-game-scene-struggling}}</ref> ; {{anchor|nothing}} nothing : When a player only has the possibility of a high card and no other hand that will win. ; {{anchor|nothing card}} nothing card : In [[community card poker]], a newly revealed community card that does not affect the value of any player's hand. ; {{anchor|nut hand (the nuts)}} nut hand (the nuts) : The ''nut hand'' is the best possible hand in a given situation. Players sometimes evaluate hands by ranking them as being the ''second nuts'' or the ''pure nuts''. ; {{anchor|nut low}} nut low : The best possible low hand in [[high-low split]] games
== O == ; {{anchor|offsuit}} offsuit : Cards that are not of the same suit ; {{anchor|one-chip rule}} one-chip rule : A call of a previous bet using a chip of a higher denomination than necessary is considered a call unless it is verbally announced as a raise. ; {{anchor|one-eyed royals}} one-eyed royals : See main article: [[one-eyed royals]] ; {{anchor|one-ended straight draw}} one-ended straight draw : Four out of the five cards needed for a straight that can only be completed with one specific rank of card, in cases where the needed card rank is either higher or lower than the cards already held as part of the sequence; as opposed to an inside straight draw or an open-ended straight draw. : While A-2-3-4 and A-K-Q-J are the only truly one-ended straight draw possibilities, an open-ended straight draw could be considered one-ended if one of the card ranks needed to complete it would also give an opponent a hand of higher rank than a straight. ; {{anchor|open}} open : To bet first. See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Open|open]] ; {{anchor|open-ended straight draw}} open-ended straight draw, open-ended : An [[Draw (poker)#Outside straight draw|outside straight draw]]. Also ''two-way straight draw'' or ''double-ended straight draw'' ; {{anchor|openers}} openers : The cards held by a player in a game of jackpots entitling them to open the pot. ''Splitting openers'' refers to holding onto one of the openers after discarding it as proof of having the necessary cards to open. ; {{anchor|open limp}} open limp : Being the first person in the pot preflop, but not raising ; {{anchor|option}} option : An optional bet or draw : The right to raise possessed by the [[Blind (poker)|big blind]] if there have been no raises. ; {{anchor|ourbit}} orbit : A full rotation of the blinds at a table, equal to the number of people at the table. ; {{anchor|outs}} outs : See main article: [[out (poker)|out]] ; {{anchor|out of position}} out of position, : A player is said to be out of position, if they are either first to act, or are not last to act in a betting round. ; {{anchor|outside straight draw}} outside straight draw : See main article: [[Draw (poker)#Outside straight draw|outside straight draw]]. Also ''two-way straight draw'' or ''double-ended straight draw'' ; {{anchor|overbet}} overbet : To make a bet that is more than the size of the pot in a no limit game ; {{anchor|overcall}} overcall : To call a bet after others have called. Compare with ''[[#cold call|cold call]]'', ''[[#flat call|flat call]]'', ''[[#smooth call|smooth call]]'' ; {{anchor|overcard}} overcard : A community card with a higher rank than a player's pocket pair : A higher card ; {{anchor|overpair}} overpair :In community card games such as [[Texas hold 'em]] and [[Omaha hold 'em]], a pocket pair with a higher rank than the highest community card. ;overs :An option to increase the stakes in limit games. Players may elect to play or not play overs. Those who choose to play display some sort of token. If, at the beginning of a betting round, only overs players remain in the hand, bets of a predetermined increased limit (or no limit) are allowed. Most often used in lower limit live games as a compromise between aggressive and passive play.
== P == ; {{anchor|paint}} paint : Any [[#royal cards|royal card]]. Used mostly in [[lowball (poker)|lowball]] games, where royal cards are rarely helpful. ; {{anchor|pair}} pair : Two cards of the same rank. See main article: [[one pair]] ; {{anchor|passive}} passive : A style of play characterized by checking and calling. Compare with ''[[#aggressive|aggressive]]'', ''[[#loose|loose]]'', ''[[#tight|tight]]'' ; {{anchor|pat}} pat :Already complete. A hand is a pat hand when, for example, a [[Flush (poker)|flush]] comes on the first five cards dealt in [[draw poker]]. Also see [[made hand]] ; {{anchor|pay off}} pay off : To call a bet when the player is most likely [[#drawing dead|drawing dead]] because the [[#pot odds|pot odds]] justify the call. ; {{anchor|penny ante}} penny ante : Frivolous, low stakes, or for fun only; a game where no significant stake is likely to change hands. ; {{anchor|perfect}} perfect :The best possible cards, in a lowball hand, after those already named. ; {{anchor|pick-up}} pick-up : When the house picks up cash from the dealer after a player buys chips ; {{anchor|play the board}} play the board : In games such as [[Texas hold 'em]], where five community cards are dealt, if the player's best hand is on the [[#board|board]] and the player goes to the [[#showdown|showdown]] they are said to ''play the board''. ; {{anchor|pocket cards}} pocket cards : See [[#hole|hole cards]] ; {{anchor|pocket pair}} pocket pair : In [[community card poker]] or [[stud poker]], when two of a player's private cards make a pair. Also ''wired pair'' ; {{anchor|poker face}} poker face : A [[blank expression]] that does not reveal anything about the cards being held. ; {{anchor|polarized}} polarized : when someone's range is split into either very strong hands or bluffs ; {{anchor|position}} position : See main article: [[position (poker)|position]] ; {{anchor|position bet}} position bet : A bet that is made more due to the strength of the bettor's [[Position (poker)|position]] than the strength of the bettor's cards. ; {{anchor|post}} post : To make the required small or big [[Blind (poker)|blind]] bet in [[Texas hold 'em]] or other games played with blinds rather than antes. ; {{anchor|post dead}} post dead : To post a bet amount equal to the small and the big blind combined (the amount of the large blind playing as a live blind, and the amount of the small blind as dead money). In games played with blinds, a player who steps away from the table and misses their turn for the blinds must either post dead or wait for the big blind to re-enter the game. Compare with ''dead blind'' ; {{anchor|post oak bluff}} post oak bluff : See main article: [[post oak bluff]] ; {{anchor|pot}} pot : See main article: [[pot (poker)|pot]] ; {{anchor|pot-committed}} pot-committed : More often in the context of a [[Betting (poker)#No limit|no limit]] game; the situation where one can no longer fold because the size of the [[#pot|pot]] is so large compared to the size of one's [[#stack|stack]]. ; {{anchor|pot-limit}} pot-limit : See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Pot limit|pot limit]] ; {{anchor|pot odds}} pot odds : See main article: [[pot odds]] ; {{anchor|pre-flop}} pre-flop : The time when players already have their pocket cards but no flop has been dealt yet. ; {{anchor|probe bet}} probe bet : A bet after the flop by a player who did not take the lead in betting before the flop (and when the player that did take the lead in betting before the flop declined to act). Compare with ''continuation bet'' ; {{anchor|prop}} prop, proposition player : A player who gets paid an hourly rate to start poker games or to help them stay active. Prop players play with their own money, which distinguishes them from shills, who play with the house's money. ; {{anchor|protected pot}} protected pot : A pot that seems impossible to bluff to win because too many players are active in it and the chances of another player either calling to the end or raising beyond measure become an assurance. ; {{anchor|protection}} protection, protect : See main article: [[protection (poker)|protection]] ; {{anchor|purse}} purse : The total prize pool in a poker tournament ; {{anchor|push}} push : To bet [[#all in|all in]] ; {{anchor|put the clock (on someone)}} put the clock (on someone) : See main article: [[#call the clock|call the clock]] ; {{anchor|put on}} put on :To ''put someone on'' a hand is to deduce what hand or range of hands they have based on their actions and knowledge of their gameplay style. See also [[#tell|tells]]
== Q == ; {{anchor|quads}} quads : [[#four of a kind|Four of a kind]] ; {{anchor|qualifier}} qualifier, qualifying low : A qualifying [[lowball (poker)|low hand]]. [[High-low split]] games often require a minimum hand value, such as eight-high, in order to award the low half of the [[pot (poker)|pot]]. In some home games, there are qualifiers for high hands as well. ; {{anchor|quartered}} quartered : To win a quarter of a pot, usually by tying the low or high hand of a [[high-low split]] game. Generally, this is an unwanted outcome, as a player is often putting in a third of the pot in the hope of winning a quarter of the pot back.
== R == ; {{anchor|rabbit hunt}} rabbit hunt : After a hand is complete, to reveal cards that would have been dealt later in the hand had it continued. This is usually prohibited in casinos because it slows the game and may reveal information about concealed hands. Also ''fox hunt'' ; {{anchor|raccoon}} raccoon : A poor player. See also [[#fish|fish]] : To make calls based on the hopes of hitting runner-runner, inside, or backdoor draws ; {{anchor|rack}} rack : A collection of 100 chips of the same denomination, usually arranged in five stacks in a plastic tray. : A plastic tray used for storing a rack of chips ; {{anchor|race}} race : See [[#coin flip|coin flip]] ; {{anchor|rag}} rag : A low-valued (and presumably worthless) card. Hence ''ragged'' - having a low value ; {{anchor|rail}} rail : The rail is the sideline at a poker table—the (often imaginary) rail separates spectators from the field of play. Watching from the rail means watching a poker game as a spectator. ''Going to the rail'' usually means losing all one's money. ; {{anchor|railbird}} railbird : A non-participatory spectator of a poker game ; {{anchor|rainbow}} rainbow : Three or four cards of different suits, especially said of a [[#flop|flop]]. : Betting a rainbow: to make a bet of one chip of each colour currently in play. ; {{anchor|raise}} raise : See main article: [[Betting (poker)#Raise|raise]] ; {{anchor|rake}} rake : See main article: [[rake (poker)|rake]]. Also ''juice'', ''vig'', ''[[#vigorish|vigorish]]'' ; {{anchor|rakeback}} rakeback : Rebate or repayment to a player a portion of the [[Rake (poker)|rake]] paid by that player, normally from a non-cardroom, third-party source such as an [[Affiliate marketing|affiliate]]. Rakeback is paid in many ways by online poker rooms, affiliates or brick and mortar rooms. Many use direct money payments for online poker play. Brick and mortar rooms usually use rate cards to track and pay their rakeback. See main article: [[Rake (poker)#Rakeback|rakeback]] ; {{anchor|Rakeback pro}} rakeback pro : A rakeback pro is a poker player who may not be a winning player but uses rakebacks to supplement their losses and turn them into winnings. ; {{anchor|range of hands}} range of hands : The list of holdings that a player considers an opponent might have when trying to deduce their holding. See also ''put on'' ; {{anchor|rathole}} rathole : To remove a portion of one's chips from the table while the game is underway. Normally prohibited in public card rooms. Also ''going south'' ; {{anchor|rebuy}} rebuy : An amount of chips purchased after the buy-in. In some tournaments, players are allowed to rebuy chips one or more times for a limited period after the start of the game, providing that their stack is at or under its initial level. Compare with ''[[#add-on|add-on]]'' ; {{anchor|redeal}} redeal : To deal a hand again, possibly after a misdeal ; {{anchor|redraw}} redraw : To make one hand and have a draw for a better hand : Second or later draws in a draw game with multiple draws ; {{anchor|represent}} represent : To ''represent'' a hand is to play as if it were held (whether it is or not). ; {{anchor|reraise}} reraise : Raise after one has been raised. Also ''coming over the top'' ; {{anchor|ring game}} ring game : See main article: [[Cash game|ring game]] ; {{anchor|river}} river : The ''river'' or ''river card'' is the final card dealt in a poker hand, to be followed by a final round of betting and, if necessary, a [[Showdown (poker)|showdown]].
