In [[Texas hold 'em]] and [[Omaha hold'em]], the river is the fifth and last card to be dealt to the community card board, after the [[#flop|flop]] and [[#turn|turn]]. A player losing the pot due only to the river card is said to have been ''rivered''. ; {{anchor|rock}} rock : A very [[#tight|tight]] player (plays very few hands and only continues with strong hands). : A bundle of chips held together with a rubber band, or other token signifying an obligatory [[Straddle (poker)|live straddle]]. If the player [[#under the gun|under the gun]] has the rock, they must use it to post a live straddle. The winner of the pot collects the rock and is obligated to use it in turn. ; {{anchor|roll your own}} roll your own : In [[seven-card stud]], when the player has some ability to choose which cards are turned face up.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pagat.com/poker/variants/rollyourown.html}}</ref> ; {{anchor|rolled-up trips}} rolled-up trips : In [[seven-card stud]], three of a kind dealt in the first three cards ; {{anchor|rounder}} rounder : An expert player who travels to seek out high-stakes games ; {{anchor|royal cards}} royal cards : Royal card are also known as ''face cards'' and ''picture cards''. These cards consist of the jack, queen, and king of every suit. ; {{anchor|royal flush}} royal flush : A [[straight flush]] of the top five cards of any suit. This is generally the highest possible hand. ; {{anchor|run it twice}} run it twice, running it twice : A gentleman's agreement (not allowed in some casinos) where the players (usually two or three) agree to draw each remaining card to come in two different occasions instead of just once after all parties have gone all-in (two flops, turns and river for example for a total of 10 community cards in two sets of five). The winner of one ''run'' gets half the pot while the winner of the second ''run'' gets the other half. Running it twice is done to minimize bad beats and reduce bankroll swings. Running it twice is a form of [[#insurance|insurance]]. ; {{anchor|runner-runner}} runner-runner : A hand made by hitting two consecutive cards on the [[#turn|turn]] and [[#river|river]]. Also ''[[#backdoor|backdoor]]''. Compare with ''[[#bad beat|bad beat]]'' and ''[[#suck out|suck out]]'' ; {{anchor|rush}} rush : A prolonged winning streak. A player who has won several big pots recently is said to be ''on a rush''. Also ''heater''
== S == ; {{anchor|sandbag}} sandbag : See [[slow play (poker)]] ; {{anchor|satellite}} satellite : A tournament in which the prize is a free entrance to another (larger) tournament. ; {{anchor|scare card}} scare card : A card dealt face up (either to a player in a game such as stud or to the board in a community card game) that could create a strong hand for someone. ; {{anchor|scoop}} scoop : In high-low split games, to win both the high and the low halves of the pot. ; {{anchor|second pair}} second pair :In [[community card poker]] games, a pair of cards of the second-top rank on the [[#board|board]]. Second pair is a [[#middle pair|middle pair]], but not necessarily vice versa. Compare with ''[[#bottom pair|bottom pair]]'', ''[[#top pair|top pair]]'' ; {{anchor|sell}} sell :In [[Betting in poker#Spread limit|spread limit]] poker, to ''sell'' a hand is to bet less than the maximum with a strong hand, in the hope that more opponents will call the bet. ; {{anchor|semi-bluff}} semi-bluff : When a player bluffs on one round of betting with an inferior or drawing hand that might improve in a later round. See main article: [[Bluff (poker)#Semi-bluff|semi-bluff]] ; {{anchor|set}} set : [[Three-of-a-kind|Three of a kind]], especially a situation where two of the cards are concealed in the player's [[#hole|hole]] cards. Compare with ''[[#three of a kind|trips]]'' ; {{anchor|set-up}} set-up : A deck that has been ordered, usually king to ace by suit (spades, hearts, clubs and diamonds). In casinos, it is customary to use a set-up deck when introducing a new deck to the table. The set-up is spread face up for the players to demonstrate that all of the cards are present before the first shuffle. Also called ''spading the deck'' ; {{anchor|sevens rule}} sevens rule : A rule in many A-5 [[lowball (poker)|lowball]] games that requires a player with a seven-low or better after the draw to bet, rather than [[Betting in poker|check]] or [[check-raise]]. In some venues, a violator loses any future interest in the pot; in others they forfeit their interest entirely. ; {{anchor|shark}} shark : A professional player. See also [[card sharp]] ; {{anchor|shill}} shill : See main article: [[Shill#Gambling|shill]]. Compare with ''proposition player'' ; {{anchor|shoe}} shoe : A slanted container used to hold the cards yet to be dealt, usually used by casinos and in professional poker tournaments. See main article: [[shoe (cards)]]. ; {{anchor|shootout}} shootout : A [[poker tournament]] format where the last remaining player of a table goes on to play the remaining players of other tables. Each table plays independently of the others; that is, there is no balancing as players are eliminated. ; {{anchor|short buy}} short buy : In [[Betting in poker#No limit|no-limit]] poker, to buy into a game for considerably less money than the stated maximum buyin, or less than other players at the table have in play. ; {{anchor|short stack}} short stack : A stack of [[casino token|chips]] that is relatively small for the stakes being played. Compare with ''[[#deep stack|deep stack]]'', ''[[#big stack|big stack]]'' ; {{anchor|shorthanded}} shorthanded : A poker game that is played with six players or fewer, as opposed to a full ring game, which is usually nine or ten players. A tournament where all tables are shorthanded at all times is called a ''short table tournament''. ; {{anchor|shove}} shove : To bet [[#all in|all in]] ; {{anchor|showdown}} showdown : When, if more than one player remains after the last betting round, remaining players expose and compare their hands to determine the winner or winners. See main article: [[showdown (poker)|showdown]] ; {{anchor|side game}} side game : A [[Cash game|ring game]] running concurrently with a [[poker tournament|tournament]] made up of players who have either been eliminated or opted not to play the tournament. ; {{anchor|side pot}} side pot : A separate pot created to deal with the situation of one player going "all in". See [[Betting in poker#Side pots|Betting in poker]] ; {{anchor|sit and go}} sit and go : A [[poker tournament]] with no scheduled starting time that starts whenever the necessary players have put up their money. Single-table sit-and-gos, with nine or ten players, are the norm, but multi-table games are common as well. Also called ''sit 'n gos'' ; {{anchor|slow play}}slow play : See main article: [[slow play (poker)|slow play]] ; {{anchor|slow roll}} slow roll : To delay or avoid showing the winning hand at showdown, it is widely regarded as poor etiquette. ; {{anchor|small blind}} small blind : See main article: [[Betting in poker#Blinds|blinds]] ; {{anchor|snow}} smooched : When someone manages to catch a slightly better hand. ; {{anchor|smooth call}} smooth call : See [[#flat call|flat call]] ; {{anchor|snap call}} snap call : When a player makes a swift call without any forethought (usually against an all-in) because of the high strength of their hand. ; {{anchor|snow}} snow : To play a worthless hand misleadingly in [[draw poker]] in order to [[Bluff (poker)|bluff]]. : The worthless hand in question ; {{anchor|soft-play}} soft-play : To intentionally go easy on a player. Soft play is expressly prohibited in most card rooms, and may result in penalties ranging from forced sit-outs to forfeiture of stakes or winnings. ; {{anchor|soft break}} soft break : Exchanging a large bill or chip into both chips and cash, when a player buys in. The cash is returned to the player and thus not in play. ; {{anchor|splash the pot}} splash the pot : To throw one's chips in the pot in a disorderly fashion. Not typically allowed, because the dealer can not tell how much has been bet. ; {{anchor|split}} split : See main article: [[split (poker)|split]] and [[high-low split]] ; {{anchor|split two pair}} split two pair :In [[community card poker]], a [[two pair]] hand, with each pair made of one of a player's [[#hole, hole cards|hole cards]], and one community card. ; {{anchor|spread}} spread : The range between a table's minimum and maximum bets ; {{anchor|spread-limit}} spread-limit : A form of [[#limit|limit]] poker where the bets and raises can be between a minimum and maximum value. The [[#spread|spread]] may change between rounds. ; {{anchor|squeeze play}} squeeze play : A bluff reraise in [[no limit (poker)|no limit]] [[hold'em]] with less-than-premium cards, after another player or players have already called the original raise. The goal is to bluff everyone out of the hand and steal the bets. ; {{anchor|stack}} stack : The total chips and currency that a player has in play at a given moment : A collection of 20 [[poker chip]]s of the same denomination, usually arranged in an orderly column ; {{anchor|stakes}} stakes : The amount one buys in for and can bet. ; {{anchor|staking}} staking : Staking is the act of one person putting up cash for a poker player to play with in hopes that the player wins. Any profits are split on a predetermined percentage between the backer and the player. A backed player is often known as a ''horse''. Compare with ''bankroll'' ; {{anchor|stand pat}} stand pat : In [[draw poker]], playing the original hand using no draws, either as a bluff or in the belief it is the best hand. ; {{anchor|starting hand}} starting hand : See main article: [[starting hand]] ; {{anchor|steal}} steal : See main article: [[steal (poker)|steal]] ; {{anchor|steam}} steam : A state of anger, mental confusion, or frustration in which a player adopts a less than optimal strategy, usually resulting in poor play. Compare with ''[[#tilt|tilt]]'' ; {{anchor|stop and go}} stop and go : When a player bets into another player who has previously raised or otherwise shown [[Aggression (poker)|aggression]]. : Another version of the ''stop and go'' is in tournament poker when a player raises pre-flop with the intention of going all in after the flop regardless of the cards that fall. ; {{anchor|straddle bet}} straddle bet : See main article: [[Betting in poker#Straddle and sleeper bets|straddle bets]] ; {{anchor|straight}} straight : Poker hand: see main article: [[Straight (poker)|straight]] : When used with an amount, indicates that the speaker is referring to the total bet, versus the amount being raised. Also ''altogether'' or ''all day'' ; {{anchor|straight flush}} straight flush : See main article: [[straight flush]] ; {{anchor|strategy card}} strategy card : A wallet sized card that is commonly used to help with poker strategies in online and casino games. ; {{anchor|street}} street : A street is another term for a dealt card or betting round. ; {{anchor|string bet}} string bet : A call with one motion and a later raise with another, or a reach for more chips without stating the intended amount. String bets are prohibited in [[Public cardroom rules (poker)|public cardroom rules]]. Compare with ''[[#forward motion|forward motion]]'' ; {{anchor|structured}} structured : A structured betting system is one where the [[#spread|spread]] of the bets may change from round to round. ; {{anchor|stud}} stub : The remainder of cards that have not been used during the active play of a particular game. ; {{anchor|stud}} stud : A variant of poker. See main article: [[stud poker]] : A card dealt face up in stud poker ; {{anchor|subscription poker}} subscription poker : Subscription poker is a form of online poker wherein users pay a monthly fee to become eligible to play in real-money tournaments. ; {{anchor|suck out}} suck out : A situation when a hand heavily favored to win loses to an inferior hand after all the cards are dealt. The winning hand is said to have ''sucked out''. Compare with ''[[bad beat]]'' ; {{anchor|suited}} suited : Having the same suit. See [[Suit (cards)|card suits]] ; {{anchor|suited connectors}} suited connectors : See main article: [[suited connectors]] ; {{anchor|super satellite}} super satellite : A multi-table [[poker tournament]] in which the prize is a free entrance to a satellite tournament or a tournament in which all the top finishers gain entrance to a larger tournament.
== T == ; {{anchor|table stakes}} table stakes : See main article: [[table stakes]]. ; {{anchor|tag}} tag : A tight aggressive style of play in which a player plays a small number of strong starting hands, but when in pots plays aggressively. ; {{anchor|tainted outs}} tainted outs : Cards that improve a hand so that it is better than the other current hands, but simultaneously improve other hands even more. See also [[#outs|outs]] ; {{anchor|tank}} tank, in the tank : To take an excessive amount of time to act. ; {{anchor|tell}} tell : A tell in poker is a detectable change in a player's behavior or demeanor that gives clues to that player's assessment of their hand. See main article: [[tell (poker)|tell]] ; {{anchor|texture}} texture : How well coordinated the community cards are to one another. This is used to estimate relative hand strength. See also [[#dry board|dry board]] and [[#wet board|wet board]] ; {{anchor|third man walking}} third man walking : A player who gets up from their seat in a [[#cash game|cash game]], after two other players are already away from the table, is referred to as the ''third man walking''. In a casino with a ''third man walking rule'', this player may be required to return to their seat within 10 minutes, or one rotation of the deal around the table, or else their seat in the game will be forfeited if there is a waiting list for the game. ; {{anchor|three bet}} three bet, three betting : To be the first player to put in a third unit of betting. ; {{anchor|three of a kind}} three of a kind : See main article: [[Three-of-a-kind|three of a kind]]. Also ''[[#trips|trips]]'', ''[[#set|set]]'' ; {{anchor|tight}} tight : To play fewer hands than average for the game or for the player normally. See [[Poker strategy#Loose/tight play|loose/tight play]]. Compare with ''[[#loose|loose]]'', ''[[#aggressive|aggressive]]'', ''[[#passive|passive]]'' ; {{anchor|tilt}} tilt : Emotional upset, mental confusion, or frustration in which a player adopts a less than optimal strategy, usually resulting in poor play. See main article: [[Tilt (poker)|tilt]]. Compare with ''[[#steam|steam]]'' ; {{anchor|to go}} to go : The amount that a player is required to call in order to stay in the hand. ; {{anchor|toke}} toke : In a [[#brick & mortar|brick and mortar]] casino, a ''toke'' is a tip given to the dealer by the winner of the pot. ; {{anchor|top kicker}} top kicker : In [[community card poker]] games, ''top kicker'' is the best possible [[#kicker|kicker]] to some given hand. ; {{anchor|top pair}} top pair : In [[community card poker]] games, ''top pair'' is a [[List of poker hands#One pair|pair]] comprising a pocket card and the highest-ranking card on the [[#board|board]]. Compare with ''[[#second pair|second pair]]'', ''[[#bottom pair|bottom pair]]'' ; {{anchor|top two}} top two : A [[#split two pair|split two pair]], matching the highest-ranking two flop cards. ; {{anchor|trap}}trap : See [[slow play (poker)|slow play]] ; {{anchor|trey}} trey : A three-spot card. ; {{anchor|turbo}} turbo : A type of tournament where the blind levels increase much faster than in standard play. ; {{anchor|turn}} turn : The ''turn'', ''turn card'' or ''fourth street'' is the fourth of five cards dealt to a community card board, constituting one face-up community card that each of the players in the game can use to make up their final hand. See also [[#flop|flop]] and [[#river|river]]
== U == ; {{anchor|under the gun}} under the gun : The playing position to the direct left of the blinds in [[Texas hold 'em]] or [[Omaha hold 'em]]. The player who is under the gun must act first on the first round of betting. ; {{anchor|underdog}} underdog : An ''underdog'' or ''dog'' is a player with a smaller chance to win than another specified player. Frequently used when the exact odds are expressed. ; {{anchor|underfull}} underfull : A full house made where the three of a kind has lower-ranking cards than the pair. Compare with ''[[#big full|big full]]'' ; {{anchor|up}} up : When used with a card rank to describe a poker hand, refers to [[two pair]] with the named card being the higher pair. ; {{anchor|upcard}} upcard : A card that is played face up. See main article: [[upcard]] ; {{anchor|upswing}} upswing : A period during which a player wins more (or loses less) than expected. See also: [[#downswing|downswing]] ; {{anchor|up the ante}} up the ante : Increase the stakes ; {{anchor|upstairs}} upstairs : See [[#raise|raise]]
== V == ; {{anchor|value bet}} value bet : A bet made by a player who wants it to be called (as opposed to a bluff or protection bet). See [[value (poker)|value]] ; {{anchor|variance}} variance : The statistical measure of how far actual results differ from expectation. See main article: [[variance]] ; {{anchor|vigorish}} vigorish, vig : The [[rake (poker)|rake]]. See main article: [[vigorish]] ; {{anchor|VPIP}} VPIP : ''Voluntary put money in pot''. Represents the percentage of hands with which a player puts money into the pot pre-flop, without counting any blind postings. VPIP is an excellent measure of how ''tight'' or ''loose'' a player is.
== W == ; {{anchor|wake up}} wake up : To "wake up with a hand" means to discover a strong starting hand, often when there has already been action in front of the player. ; {{anchor|walk}} walk : A situation where all players fold to the big blind. ; {{anchor|wash}} wash : To mix the deck by spreading the cards face down on the table and mixing them up. ; {{anchor|weak ace}} weak ace : An ace with a low kicker. Also ''small ace'', ''soft ace'', ''ace-rag'' ; {{anchor|weak player}} weak player : A player who is easily bullied out of a hand post-flop by any sort of action. ; {{anchor|webcam poker}} webcam poker : A form of online poker which allows players to watch each other during play via a webcam. ; {{anchor|wet board}} wet board : A ''wet board'' is when the cards on the table make it possible for players to have hit strong hands. Compare with ''[[#dry board|dry board]]'' ; {{anchor|wheel}} wheel : A five-high straight (A-2-3-4-5), with the ace playing low. See [[List of poker hands#Straight|list of poker hands]] and [[Lowball (poker)#Wheel|lowball (poker)]] : In [[Deuce-to-seven|deuce-to-seven lowball]], the nut low hand (2-3-4-5-7) ; {{anchor|wild card}} wild card : See main article: [[wild card (poker)|wild card]]. Compare with ''[[bug (poker)|bug]]'' ; {{anchor|window card}} window card : An upcard in [[stud poker]]. The first window card in stud is called the ''door card''. In Texas hold'em and Omaha, the window card is the first card shown when the dealer puts out the three cards for the flop. ; {{anchor|wrap}} wrap : In [[Omaha hold 'em]], a wrap is a straight draw with nine or more outs<ref>[http://www.countingouts.com CountingOuts.com]</ref> comprising two board cards and three or four cards from a player's hand.
==See also== {{Portal|Sports and games}} * [[Poker]] * [[Betting in poker]] {{clr}}
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070701225836/http://www.poker1.com/mcu/pokerdictionary/mculib_dictionary_info.asp The Official Dictionary of Poker] by [[Michael Wiesenberg]] *[http://www.seriouspoker.com/dictionary.html Dan Kimberg's Poker Dictionary]

{{Infobox venue | name = Goodall Park | nickname = | image = [[File:Goodall Park.JPG|200px]] | location = Roberts Street, [[Sanford, Maine]], [[United States of America|USA]] | coordinates = {{coord|43.436286|-70.777096|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = May 29, 1915 | renovated = 2003 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Natural grass | scoreboard = Electronic | construction_cost = | suites = | architect = | capacity = 950 | record_attendance = | dimensions = '''Left Field:''' {{convert|321|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Left Center Field:''' {{convert|346|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Deep Left Center Field:''' {{convert|378|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Center Field:''' {{convert|404|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Deep Right Center Field:''' {{convert|384|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Right Center Field:''' {{convert|350|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Right Field:''' {{convert|283|ft|m|sp=us}} | tenants = [[Sanford Mainers]] ([[New England Collegiate Baseball League|NECBL]]) (2002-present) }} '''Goodall Park''' is a [[baseball]] venue in [[Sanford, Maine]], United States, which is home to the [[Sanford Mainers]] of the [[New England Collegiate Baseball League]]. The park opened in 1915. It has a seating capacity of 950 spectators. ==History== [[File:Goodall Park Entrance.JPG|thumb|left|250px|The rear of the park's rebuilt grandstand.]] The park opened on May 29, 1915. Its first game was between the [[Sanford Professionals]] and the [[Lewiston Pilgrims]] (of [[Lewiston, Maine]]). The game was played in front of 1,300 fans.http://www.sanfordmainers.com/news/news070603b.htm Sanford Mainers website, URL accessed November 27, 2008 In 1919, the park hosted an exhibition game between the Sanford Professionals and the [[Boston Red Sox]]. The game was [[Babe Ruth]]'s last game in a Red Sox uniform. Ruth hit a three-run [[home run]] to lead the Red Sox to a come-from-behind 4-3 victory. Ruth did not play in another game for the Red Sox before being traded to the [[New York Yankees]] by Red Sox owner [[Harry Frazee]].http://www.digitalballparks.com/NECBL/Goodall7.html Goodall Park gallery, URL accessed December 13, 2008http://bostonherald.com/sports/red_sox_mlb/mlb_coverage/2012/07/maine%E2%80%99s_field_dreams ===1997 fire and rebuilding=== In 1997, an [[arsonist]] set fire to the park's grandstand and destroyed it. After debate in Sanford as to whether or not to rebuild the park, the grandstand was rebuilt in 1998 and rededicated on July 16, 1999. The grandstand was rebuilt at a cost of over [[USD|$]]1 million. ===Seating areas=== Most of the park's 950-spectator capacity comes from the grandstand located directly behind home plate. The grandstand consists entirely of chairbacked seats. The park also has a section of metal bleacher seating located down the first base line. ==Photo gallery== File:Goodall Park Scoreboard.JPG|The park's electronic scoreboard, located over the left center field fence. File:Goodall Park Bullpen.JPG|The visitors [[bullpen]], located down the right field line. File:Goodall Park Press Box.JPG|The [[press box]], located above grandstand seating directly behind home plate. File:Goodall Park Plaque.JPG|A plaque, located within the grandstand, that commemorates the park's rebuilding after it was destroyed by an arsonist. File:Goodall Park Concessions.JPG|The park's main concession stand. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.necbl.com NECBL website] * [http://www.sanfordmainers.com Sanford Mainers website] * [http://www.digitalballparks.com/NECBL/Goodall.html Goodall Park gallery at digitalballparks.com] {{NECBL Ballparks}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Maine]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:New England Collegiate Baseball League ballparks]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in York County, Maine]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Sanford, Maine]] [[Category:1915 establishments in Maine]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1915]]

[[Utica, Michigan]] 48317 | location = | coordinates = | type = [[Baseball]] | genre = | broke_ground = June 23, 2015 | built = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = General Sports and Entertainment | operator = General Sports and Entertainment | surface = Grass | scoreboard = Yes | production = | cost = [[United States dollar|$]]15 million | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 4,500 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = '''Left Field''' - {{Convert|315|ft|m|0}}
'''Center Field''' - {{Convert|395|ft|m|0}}
'''Right Field''' - {{Convert|320|ft|m|0}}{{cite web|title=Jimmy John's Field|url=http://www.intheballparks.com/uspbl/jimmy-johns|website=In The Ballparks|accessdate=22 February 2017}} | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = Utica Unicorns ([[United Shore Professional Baseball League|USPBL]]) (2016-present)
Birmingham-Bloomfield Beavers (USPBL) (2016-present)
Eastside Diamond Hoppers (USPBL) (2016-present)
Westside Woolly Mammoths (USPBL) (2017-present) | embedded = | website = https://uspbl.com/ballpark/ | publictransit = }} '''Jimmy John's Field''' is a [[baseball field]] in [[Utica, Michigan]], home to four teams that play in the [[United Shore Professional Baseball League]] (USPBL), an independent baseball league. It opened on May 30, 2016 where the Utica Unicorns defeated the Birmingham-Bloomfield Beavers, 5-1.{{cite web|title=Scoreboard: May 30, 2016|url=http://uspbl.wttbaseball.pointstreak.com/scoreboard.html?leagueid=1861&seasonid=30320&date=05/30/2016|website=United Shore Professional Baseball League|accessdate=22 February 2017}} Naming rights were purchased by [[Jimmy John's]], a sandwich restaurant chain.{{cite news|last1=Spedden|first1=Zach|title=Ballpark Preview: Jimmy John's Field|url=http://ballparkdigest.com/2016/02/01/ballpark-preview-jimmy-johns-field/|accessdate=22 February 2017|agency=Ballpark Digest|publisher=Independent Baseball News|date=1 February 2016}} ==History== The ballpark is located in downtown Utica, just outside of [[Detroit, Michigan|Detroit]]. Jimmy John's Field is owned by General Sports Entertainment (GSE), however Utica's Downtown Development Authority will own the land it sits on and lease it to them for $1 per year for 30 years. The property was the site of a capped brownfield landfill that served as an unlicensed dump for household waste, that sat vacant the last 80 years.{{cite news|last1=Hall|first1=Christina|title=Names, mascots unveiled for teams at new Utica stadium|url=http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/macomb/2015/11/23/utica-baseball-team-names/76255308/|accessdate=22 February 2017|publisher=Detroit Free Press|date=23 November 2015}} General Sports created the USPBL. The USPBL is the first independent professional baseball league in the metropolitan Detroit area.{{cite web|title=Our Divisions: United Shore Pro Baseball League|url=http://www.generalsports.com/divisions.php?id=4|website=General Sports|accessdate=22 February 2017}} Construction began in June 2015 and the venue opened on May 30, 2016. The cost of the field was $15 million.{{cite news|last1=Reichard|first1=Kevin|title=New Utica Ballpark a Springboard for League Expansion|url=http://ballparkdigest.com/2016/05/30/new-utica-ballpark-a-springboard-for-league-expansion/|accessdate=22 February 2017|agency=Ballpark Digest|publisher=Independent Baseball News|date=30 May 2016}} In the park's first season it served all three teams as their home field, averaging 3,200 fans per game with over 200,000 fans total.{{cite news|last1=Folsom|first1=Brandon|title=First year a home run for United Shore Professional Baseball League|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/mlb/tigers/2016/09/08/united-shore-professional-baseball-league/90105108/|accessdate=22 February 2017|publisher=Detroit Free Press|date=8 September 2016}} In its second season, it will serve as the home field for the Westside Woolly Mammoths as well. The field served as the home of the [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] [[Marygrove College#Athletics|Marygrove College Mustangs]] baseball team until athletics were dropped in December 2017.{{cite web|title=JIMMY JOHN'S FIELD|url=http://www.marygrovemustangs.com/jimmy-johns-field|website=MarygroveMustangs.com|accessdate=8 May 2017}} In addition, the park hosted an NCAA game in April 2017.{{cite news|title=OAKLAND FALLS TO CENTRAL MICHIGAN 8-4 AT JIMMY JOHN'S FIELD|url=http://www.goldengrizzlies.com/sports/m-basebl/recaps/042617aab.html|accessdate=8 May 2017|publisher=[[Oakland Golden Grizzlies]]|date=26 April 2017}} ==Venue== The stadium has a total capacity of 4,500 fans, with 2,000 box seats between first and third base. It features 7 founder's level suites, 5 dugout suites, 12 patio suites, 4 picnic areas, and a grass [[berm]]. The ballpark also features a restaurant and bar on the concourse behind home plate. In the right field corner there is a [[wiffle ball]] field and a playground. The field has extremely wide foul territories, and a concert quality speaker system, allowing it to host other sports and events in the future. Before the USPBL's second season, the stadium added 3 new bars, a concert stage in right field, and many new menu items.{{cite news|last1=Rose|first1=Justin|title=USPBL puts finishing touches on park as opening day approaches|url=http://www.wxyz.com/sports/uspbl-puts-finishing-touches-on-park-as-opening-day-approaches|accessdate=9 May 2017|publisher=[[WXYZ-TV]]|date=8 May 2017}} ==Awards== In September 2016, Jimmy John's Field won the CREW Detroit Impact Award in the special impact award category for its transformation of landfill parcels along the [[Clinton River]].{{cite news|last1=Roberts|first1=Adrienne|title=New Humane Society campus, Jimmy John's Field win CREW Impact Awards|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20160922/NEWS/160929895/new-humane-society-campus-jimmy-johns-field-win-crew-impact-awards|accessdate=22 March 2017|publisher=[[Crain's Detroit Business]]|date=22 September 2016}} In March 2017, the stadium project won the Engineering Eminent Conceptor Award from the American Council of Engineering Companies of Michigan.{{cite news|last1=Brenke|first1=Ronald|title=Michigan’s Top Engineering and Surveying Projects Recognized at Annual ACEC/M Excellence Awards Ceremony|url=http://www.acecmi.org/uploads/4/2/3/0/42305689/press_release_acec-michigan_engineering_excellence.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2017|publisher=The American Council of Engineering Companies of Michigan|date=14 March 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://uspbl.com United Shore Professional Baseball League Official Website] * [http://www.generalsports.com/ General Sports Entertainment Official Website] {{coord|42.6260|N|83.0402|W|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Michigan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Macomb County, Michigan]] [[Category:2016 establishments in Michigan]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2016]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]]

{{Infobox Stadium |stadium_name = Mediacom Ice Park |nickname = |image = |location = [[Springfield, Missouri]] |broke_ground = |opened = 2001 |closed = |demolished = |owner = Springfield-Greene County Park Board |operator = |surface = 2 rinks: 200′ × 85′ (hockey) |architect = |former_names = Jordan Valley Ice Park (2001–2008) |tenants = [[Missouri State Ice Bears]]
Springfield Spirit ([[North American Hockey League|NAHL]]) (2001–2005)
[[Springfield Wolfpack]] ([[American Professional Football League|APFL]]) (2003–2012)
[[Missouri Voodoo]] ([[Ultimate Indoor Football League|UIFL]]) (2014)
[[Springfield Express]] ([[Western States Hockey League|WSHL]]) (2014–2018) |seating_capacity = 2,000 |coordinates = {{Coord|37.21069|-93.28463|format=dms|display=inline,title|type:landmark_region:US-MO}} }} '''Mediacom Ice Park''' is a multi-purpose arena located in downtown [[Springfield, Missouri]]. The arena is owned and operated by the Springfield-Greene County Park Boardhttp://www.parkboard.org/ and serves as a location for community recreation and the home for the [[Missouri State Bears|Missouri State Ice Bears]] [[ice hockey]] team,http://missouristatehockey.com/tickets.php {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302162420/http://missouristatehockey.com/tickets.php |date=March 2, 2009 }} and various youth sports programs. The arena opened in 2001 and was previously known as the Jordan Valley Ice Park; its current name is due to a $200,000 a year, 10-year naming rights agreement with [[Mediacom]], a [[cable television]] and communications provider in the [[United States]].{{cite web |url=http://www.commercialalert.org/issues/government/corporations/mediacom-makes-bid-for-ice-park-naming-rights |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706102229/http://www.commercialalert.org/issues/government/corporations/mediacom-makes-bid-for-ice-park-naming-rights |archivedate=2010-07-06 |df= }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090219222141/http://parkboard.org/info/facilities/ice_park/index.html Official website] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Missouri]] [[Category:Sports venues in Missouri]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Missouri]] [[Category:Sports venues in Springfield, Missouri]] [[Category:2001 establishments in Missouri]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2001]] [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Arena football venues]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 845412299 by [[Special:Contributions/Narky Blert|Narky Blert]] ([[User talk:Narky Blert|talk]])
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2011}} A '''mobile bleacher''' or '''portable bleacher''' is a type of [[bleacher]] that can be moved to different locations to fulfill a need for temporary or reconfigurable seating. Some units incorporate a built-in hydraulic or electric actuation system for raising and lowering the unit. [[Highway]] towable units are available, as well as units designed to be moved within a single [[Sports venue|venue]].<ref>[[Nussli Group]] {{cite web|title=Mobile Bleacher Seating|url=http://www.nussli.com/fileadmin/content/ueber_nussli/Leitung/Verwaltungsrat/20100920_techn_datasheet__Mobile_bleacher_seating_EN_final.pdf|website=[[Nussli Group]]|format=PDF|accessdate=February 7, 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref> [[File:Mobile Bleacher.jpg|thumb|Mobile bleacher]]
In multi-purpose [[sport]]s venues, seating arrangements must be adapted to suit different sports' requirements. In indoor [[arena]]s, the activity area may vary from the size of a [[boxing ring]] to a [[football pitch]]. In [[outdoor sport]]s, field sizes may vary between [[American football]] and [[soccer]] requirements, or [[baseball field]]s. Movable seating arrangements have been created to fill this need. Mobile bleachers provide a lower-cost method of providing such seating with minimal site preparation requirements.
In the [[United States]], mobile bleachers are required to meet the same safety standards as fixed, telescopic and temporary bleachers in accordance with [[U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission|CPSC]] Publication 330.<ref name=cpsc1>{{cite web|title=Guidelines for Retrofitting Bleachers|url=http://www.cpsc.gov/cpscpub/pubs/330.pdf|publisher=U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission|format=PDF|accessdate=February 7, 2011|page=2|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Movable seating]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Nonbuilding structures]] [[Category:Sports venues]]
{{sport-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox football club | clubname = Northern Athletic F.C. | image = | fullname = Northern Athletic Association Football Club | nickname = | founded = 1992 | ground = Jurby School Playing Fields, School Close
[[Jurby]], [[Isle of Man]] | capacity = ''not known'' | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Isle of Man Football League]] [[Isle of Man Football League#Division Two|Division Two]] | season = [[2008–09 Isle of Man League|2008–09]] | position = Division Two, 13th | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | leftarm1 = 6600FF | body1 = 6600FF | rightarm1 = 6600FF | shorts1 = 6600FF | socks1 = 6600FF | pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2=| leftarm2=FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=FFFFFF|socks2=FFFFFF| }} '''Northern Athletic A.F.C.''' was a [[Association football|football]] club from [[Jurby]] in the [[Isle of Man]]. They competed in the [[Isle of Man Football League]]. They wore a purple and white kit and played their home games at the Jurby School Playing Fields. Following the 2008–09 season, the club was forced to withdraw from the [[Isle of Man Football League]] due to a lack of playing members, as a result the club has now folded. ==History== Formed in 1992, they were known as '''Jurby F.C.''' until the end of the 2007–08 season. They struggled each season in Division Two often finishing bottom of the league, and in the 2004–05 season went the entire season without winning one league game. They did get two draws and ended up with a total of two points. {{cite web | title = Isle of Man 2004/05 | publisher = [[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]] | date = 2005-01-15 | url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesm/manx05.html | accessdate = 2007-05-29}} In June 2008 the club faced extinction when they stated that unless they got a new manager the club might have to pull out of the league {{cite news | title = Jurby in public plea over manager | publisher = [[BBC Sport]] | date = 2008-06-18 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7460975.jp | accessdate = 2008-09-10}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} and in the 2008–09 they changed their name to Northern Athletic.{{cite news |title = Manx football season opens with a bang |publisher = [[Isle of Man Newspapers]] |date = 2008-07-22 |url = http://www.iomtoday.co.im/manxfootball/Manx-football-season-opens-with.4286144.jp |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130108091519/http://www.iomtoday.co.im/manxfootball/Manx-football-season-opens-with.4286144.jp |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2013-01-08 |accessdate = 2008-09-10 }} The club had a reserve team that play in the [[Isle of Man Football Combination]]. A previous club, '''RAF Jurby''', were Isle of Man League champions in 1955–56. {{cite web | title = Isle of Man List of Cup Winners | publisher = [[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]] | date = 2008-06-08 | url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesm/manxchamp.html | accessdate = 2008-09-10}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Isle of Man Football League}} [[Category:Football clubs in the Isle of Man]] [[Category:1992 establishments in the Isle of Man]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1992]] {{IsleofMan-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Pegula Ice Arena | nickname = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | address = 250 University Drive
[[University Park, Pennsylvania|University Park, PA]] 16802 | location = | coordinates = {{coord|40.80710|-77.8568|type:landmark|display=inline,title|format=dms}} | type = [[List of indoor arenas|Indoor Arena]] | genre = sporting events | broke_ground = April 20, 2012{{cite web |title=Penn State Hockey Celebrates Pegula Ice Arena Groundbreaking|url=http://www.gopsusports.com/sports/m-hockey/spec-rel/042012aae.html|publisher=Pennsylvania State University Department of Athletics|date=April 20, 2012|accessdate=March 3, 2014}} | built = | opened = {{Start date|2013|10|11|df=y}} (vs. Army) | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Pennsylvania State University]] | operator = Pennsylvania State University | surface = | scoreboard = center hung | production = | cost = $88 Million | architect = Crawford Architects
[[Bohlin Cywinski Jackson]] | project_manager = Mortenson Construction{{cite web |title=Mortenson’s Sports Group Selected for Penn State Hockey Facility—Pegula Ice Arena|url=http://www.mortenson.com/NewsArticle_2011_031711_NPG_Penn_State_Hockey_Facility.aspx|publisher=Mortenson Construction|date=March 17, 2011|accessdate=March 3, 2014}} | structural engineer = [[Thornton Tomasetti]] | services engineer = KJWW Engineering | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 6,014 (Ice hockey) | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Penn State Nittany Lions men's ice hockey|Nittany Lion Men's Ice Hockey]] (2013–present)
[[Penn State Nittany Lions women's ice hockey|Nittany Lion Women's Ice Hockey]] (2013–present) | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} The '''Pegula Ice Arena''' is a 6,014-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[University Park, Pennsylvania]] on the campus of [[Pennsylvania State University|Penn State University]]. The arena opened on October 11, 2013 when the [[Penn State Nittany Lions men's ice hockey]] hosted [[Army Black Knights men's ice hockey|Army]].{{cite web |title=Men's Hockey Opens Season, Pegula Ice Arena Friday Night|url=http://news.psu.edu/story/291064/2013/10/11/athletics/mens-hockey-opens-season-pegula-ice-arena-friday-night|publisher=Pennsylvania State University|date=October 11, 2013|accessdate=March 3, 2014}} The ice arena replaced the 1,350-seat [[Penn State Ice Pavilion]]. The facility is located on the corner of Curtin Road and University Drive near the [[Bryce Jordan Center]]. It was announced on January 21, 2011 that the arena would be named in honor of [[Kim Pegula|Kim]] and [[Terrence Pegula|Terry Pegula]] whose $100 million donation helped fund the arena and the creation of men's and women's varsity [[College ice hockey|ice hockey]] programs.{{cite web |title=Penn State Names New Arena|url=http://www.collegehockeynews.com/news/2011/01/21_penn_state_names_new_arena.php|work=College Hockey News|date=January 21, 2011|accessdate=February 7, 2011}} On September 17, 2010 it was officially announced the men's and women's ice hockey programs would move to the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] level for the 2012-13 season. The teams competed in the existing 1,350-seat Penn State Ice Pavilion until the new arena was completed in the Fall of 2013.{{cite news|title=Pegula Ice Arena to Be Open for 2013-14 Season|first=Anthony|last=Barton|url=http://www.collegian.psu.edu/archive/2011/02/07/hockey_to_psu_sooner_than_planned.aspx|newspaper=[[The Daily Collegian (Penn State)]]|date=February 7, 2011|accessdate=February 7, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110210114314/http://www.collegian.psu.edu/archive/2011/02/07/hockey_to_psu_sooner_than_planned.aspx|archivedate=February 10, 2011|df=}} Pegula Ice Arena is capable of hosting other on-ice events, including ice shows and [[National Hockey League]] and [[American Hockey League]] exhibition games.{{cite web |title=Pegulas Commit Historic Gift To Penn State For New Arena And Hockey Program|url=http://www.gopsusports.com/sports/m-hockey/spec-rel/091710aaa.html|publisher=Pennsylvania State University Department of Athletics|date=September 17, 2010|accessdate=February 7, 2011}} The first NHL exhibition game at the arena, featuring Pegula's [[Buffalo Sabres]] hosting the [[Minnesota Wild]], took place in September 2016, seeing the Minnesota Wild score the game-winning goal with less than 5 seconds in regulation for a 2-1 win.{{cite web|url=http://www.whec.com/sports/sabres-announce-2016-preseason-schedule/4184379/|title=Page Not Found|publisher=}} The Sabres will return to the arena for a preseason game in 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.gopsusports.com/sports/m-hockey/spec-rel/061917aaa.html|title=Sabres, Penguins Set For Preseason Clash at Pegula|publisher=}} The main ice arena features a main competition ice arena with seating for about 6,000 spectators. The facility also includes a practice rink, offices, locker rooms and player areas. The facility was 100% privately funded as part of the $100 million gift, the largest in the university's history, to advance the men's and women's ice hockey programs to the NCAA Division I level and provide a suitable facility for that move. On November 5, 2010 the Penn State Board of Trustees appointed [[Crawford Architects]] and [[Bohlin Cywinski Jackson]] as the architects for the new arena. Crawford Architects has worked on projects in the US and internationally and Bohlin Cywinski Jackson designed the Biobehavioral Health Building, currently under construction on the PSU campus.{{cite web |title=Trustees Appoint Architects for New Ice Arena|url=http://www.gopsusports.com/sports/m-hockey/spec-rel/110510aaa.html|publisher=Pennsylvania State University Department of Athletics|date=November 5, 2010|accessdate=February 7, 2011}} ==See also== * [[Penn State Nittany Lions men's ice hockey]] * [[Penn State Nittany Lions women's ice hockey]] * [[Penn State Nittany Lions]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.gopsusports.com/pegula-ice-arena/ Penn State Official Athletic Site - Pegula Ice Arena] {{The Pennsylvania State University}} {{Penn State Nittany Lions men's ice hockey navbox}} {{Penn State Nittany Lions women's ice hockey navbox}} {{Penn State Women's Ice Hockey Club}} {{Big Ten Conference men's ice hockey navbox}} {{College Hockey America}} [[Category:Penn State Nittany Lions ice hockey]] [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:2013 establishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2013]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Pennsylvania State University campus]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2016}}
A '''Removable Bolt''' (or "RB"), in [[climbing]], is a spring loaded metal camming device used to anchor a person or a load to a rock or cement wall temporarily. Removable Bolts negate the need to install permanent protection bolts to the wall, which can be costly and cause cosmetic damage. RBs are designed for use in bolting new sport climbing routes, setting temporary anchors on traditional routes, and on back-country expeditions where abandoning gear or placing permanent gear is not optimal. RBs are particularly popular when placing permanent bolts on steep walls with limited features, where other means of temporary protection, such as hooks, traditional camming devices, or slings, are not an option. By drilling a hole and inserting an RB, the bolter can ascend higher up on the rock before placing the next permanent piece of protection, thereby leaving a reasonable climbing distance between bolts on the finished route. RBs have also been designed and produced for fall prevention and safety in construction and mining operations.
Originally produced in the mid 1990s, removable bolts were at first reported to become permanently lodged in the rock after anchoring a fall. In the early 2000s, several companies redesigned the RB and the equipment has received positive feedback from users. RBs are used almost exclusively in bolting and cleaning new lines, often steep limestone, which is soft enough to be drilled with relative ease, and is particularly difficult to bolt without some load bearing anchor.
Removable bolts have been designed for particular climbing and industrial circumstances. ClimbTech's Kinder Edition Removable Bolt was designed for climber [http://www.joekindkid.com/ Joe Kinder], who required an RB that could be used on particularly dirty and moist rock. The additional surface area of the Kinder Edition RB provides better friction in these circumstances, and allowed Kinder and others to establish sport climbs in remote areas where variable rock quality necessitated careful bolt placement.
The typical RB is a 1/2 inch stopper designed to fit into a mechanically drilled hole. Other sizes have been developed, and further customizations continue to appear.
== References ==
{{reflist}}
*http://www.rockandice.com/lates-news/climbtech-rb-anchor-and-perma-draw *http://www.rockandice.com/lates-news/josh-wharton-the-alpinist *http://www.upskillclimbinggear.com/products/Removable-Bolt.html *http://www.dpmclimbing.com/climbing-videos/watch/climbtech-removable-bolts-rock-climbing *http://www.mountainproject.com/v/removable-bolt-trial-by-fire-by-manufacturer/107502423 *http://www.supertopo.com/climbing/thread.php?topic_id=743502 *http://www.patrollersupply.com/equipment/item_193.asp *http://www.dpmclimbing.com/articles/view/joe-kinder-bolting-next-generation

revision.text:
{{update|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Riza Lushta | nickname = | image = | location = [[Mitrovica, Kosovo|Mitrovica]], [[Kosovo]] | opened = | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Mitrovica, Kosovo|Municipality of Mitrovica]] | operator = | surface = Grass
105x68m | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[KF Trepça'89|Trepça'89]] | seating_capacity = 12,000[http://www.worldstadiums.com/europe/countries/kosovo.shtml Reference from WorldStadiums] }} '''Riza Lushta''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Mitrovica, Kosovo|Mitrovica]], [[Kosovo]] . It was named after notable Juventus player [[Riza Lushta]], who was from Mitrovica, and is used mostly for [[Association football|football]] matches and is the home ground of [[KF Trepça'89|Trepça'89]] of the [[Football Superleague of Kosovo|Kosovar Superliga]]. The stadium has a capacity of 12,000 people. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Sports Venues in Kosovo}} {{coord|42|53|17.0|N|20|51|41.1|E|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Riza Lushta Stadium}} [[Category:Mitrovica, Kosovo]] [[Category:Football venues in Kosovo|Mitrovica]] [[Category:KF Trepça'89|Stadium]] {{kosovo-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.comment: /* History */
revision.text:
{{Pro hockey team | current= 2015–16 National League B season | text_color = #FFFFFF | bg_color = #D00107 | team = SC Rapperswil-Jona Lakers | logo = Logo SC Rapperswil-Jona Lakers.svg | logosize = 220px | city = [[Rapperswil]], [[Switzerland]] | league = [[National League (ice hockey)|National League]] | conference = | division = | founded = 1945 | arena = [[St. Galler Kantonalbank Arena]] | colors = Red, white, blue
{{Color box|#D00107}} {{Color box|#FFFFFF}} {{Color box|#1B1E63}} | owner = | coach = [[Jeff Tomlinson]] | GM = | captain = [[Antonio Rizzelo]] | media = | affiliates = | name1 = SC Rapperswil-Jona | dates1 = 1945–2005 | name2 = Rapperswil-Jona Lakers | dates2 = 2005–2015 | name3 = SC Rapperswil-Jona Lakers | dates3 = 2015–present | website = [http://www.lakers.ch/ www.lakers.ch] |reg_season_titles = |division_titles = |conf_titles = |kelly_cups = }} The '''Rapperswil-Jona Lakers''' are a professional [[ice hockey]] club from [[Rapperswil]], [[Switzerland]] and are members of the [[National League (ice hockey)|National League]]. ==History== [[File:Jason Spezza – Rapperswil-Jona Lakers-HC Davos – 04.12.2012.jpg|thumb|left|[[Jason Spezza]] played for the Lakers during the [[2012–13 NHL season|NHL lockout]] in 2012–13.]] The Lakers were founded in 1945 and were known as '''SC Rapperswil-Jona''' until 2005, when the club changed its name to '''Rapperswil-Jona Lakers''' and then again changed their name to '''SC Rapperswil-Jona Lakers''' in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://swisshockeynews.ch/index.php/switzerland/nlb-new/3990-new-chapter-for-the-lakers-different-name-and-new-logo|title=New chapter for the Lakers - different name and new logo|publisher=swisshockeynew.ch|date=June 24, 2015|accessdate=February 19, 2016}} They play their home games at [[St. Galler Kantonalbank Arena]]. NHL veteran [[Doug Gilmour]] skated for the Lakers during the [[1994–95 NHL lockout|NHL lockout-shortened season]] in 1994. They had survived relegation in every NLA season since last making the playoffs in 2007-08 until 2014-15, when they were swept by the [[SCL Tigers]] in the promotion/relegation round. They returned to the [[Swiss League]] for the 2015–16 season. In season 2017-18 they've not only won the [[Swiss Cup (ice hockey)]], they also won the [[Swiss League]] Championship against [[EHC Olten]] and the promotion round against [[EHC Kloten]] and returned finally to the [[National League (ice hockey)|National League]] after 3 years in the minor league. ==Honors== ===Champions=== *'''[[National League B|NLB Championship]]''' ''(1)'': 1994 *'''[[Swiss League|Swiss League Championship]]''' ''(1)'': 2018 *'''[[Swiss Cup (ice hockey)|Swiss Cup Championship]]''' ''(1)'': 2018 ==Current roster== {{Rapperswil-Jona Lakers roster}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Rapperswil-Jona Lakers}} *[http://www.lakers.ch Rapperswil-Jona Lakers official website] {{de icon}} {{National League B}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rapperswil-Jona Lakers}} [[Category:SC Rapperswil-Jona Lakers| ]] [[Category:Ice hockey teams in Switzerland]] [[Category:Rapperswil-Jona]] [[Category:Culture of the canton of St. Gallen]] {{Switzerland-sport-team-stub}} {{Europe-icehockey-team-stub}} Pascal Wüst

revision.text:
[[File:Xavi Selección.jpg|thumb|right|110px|[[Xavi]] at [[Euro 2008]]]] In [[association football]], '''work rate''' refers to the extent to which a [[Soccer player|player]] contributes to running and chasing in a [[Game|match]] while not in possession of the ball.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://oed.com/view/Entry/230216?redirectedFrom=work%20rate|title=Definition for work rate, n.|date=30 March 2011|accessdate=15 June 2011|publisher=[[Oxford English Dictionary Online]]}}</ref>
Work rate is generally indicated by the distance covered by a player during a match. An example of a player with a high work rate is [[Xavi]], a former midfielder for [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] and [[Spain national football team|Spain]]. During the final of the [[2010–11 UEFA Champions League]], Xavi ran almost 12 km, more than any other player in the game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/thefootballtacticsblog/2011/05/barcelona_provide_a_coachs_dre.html|title=Barcelona provide a coach's dream|date=30 May 2011|accessdate=15 June 2011|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]}}</ref> The same is true of the final of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]], when he covered a distance of 14.98 km (including extra time).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/01/27/28/20/64_0711_ned-esp_playersheatmap.pdf|title=2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa Players Heat Map|date=11 July 2010|accessdate=15 June 2011|publisher=[[FIFA.com]]}}</ref>
A high work rate is valued because players with this characteristic will be able to play a more active role in [[Defense (sports)|defending]] and [[Offense (sports)|attacking]] throughout a match. Conversely, players are sometimes criticized for low work rate; for instance, [[ESPN Soccernet]] correspondent Sam Limbert highlighted a poor work rate as one of the weaker qualities of [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] midfielder [[Denílson Pereira Neves]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.soccernet.com/arsenal/archives/2011/05/time_to_renew_the_faith_1.php|title=Arsenal: Time to renew the faith|date=29 May 2011|accessdate=15 June 2011|publisher=[[ESPN Soccernet]]}}</ref>
However, some experts, such as former [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] and [[São Paulo FC|São Paulo]] youth coach Carlos de Lorenzi, warn against the danger of equating high work rate with high talent. De Lorenzi had responsibility for the early development of such players as Brazilian star [[Kaká]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/jun/04/world-cup-2010-best-players|title=World Cup 2010: Seven of the best players going to South Africa|date=4 June 2010|accessdate=15 June 2011|publisher=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://riotimesonline.com/brazil-news/front-page/brazils-world-cup-countdown/#|title=Brazil's World Cup countdown|date=8 June 2010|accessdate=15 June 2011|publisher=The Rio Times}}</ref>
